headline: Cristiano Ronaldo reveals real reason he cried at Euro 2024 after missing penalty
body: Cristiano Ronaldo burst into tears after missing a penalty for Portugal at Euro 2024, and has now explained the reason behind his emotional reaction
Cristiano Ronaldo has explained why he burst into tears after missing a crucial penalty for Portugal at Euro 2024.

The 39-year-old, who failed to score a single goal at the tournament, saw an extra time spot-kick saved by Jan Oblak during Portugal's last-16 tie with Slovenia. He was seen blubbing minutes later during an on-field team talk, but managed to rally and score in the subsequent shootout, which Portugal won 3-0.

In the aftermath, Ronaldo was relentlessly mocked on social media, with some accusing him of letting his ego get the better of him. But the Al-Nassr forward insists that couldn't be further from the truth.

"When you have passion for what you are doing, you can't be worried about how you're feeling," he said while chatting to former Manchester United team-mate Rio Ferdinand on his UR Cristiano Ronaldo YouTube channel.

"For example, I cried the day I missed the penalty... when I cried, it's not because I felt that if I don't score Portugal will be eliminated, and the world will collapse on me. It's not because of that.

"People, they don't know me. Imagine that the last 27 penalties, you score. And in that period, you feel bad for yourself. The people who come to the stadium, your kids, your mum, your girlfriend, everyone. I feel sad because of that."

Ronaldo said that when the high standards he sets for himself aren't met, it can take a toll on him emotionally. However, he insisted that's what makes him authentic. "I didn't even think about [Portugal losing]," he said.

"I felt sad because of the pressure I put on myself since I was 11-years-old. 'Cristiano Ronaldo you are the best player in the world', I'm always thinking that in my mind. And I put a lot of pressure on myself [because of that].

"So when things go wrong, you feel that. But I love that, I know how to deal with that. But when I missed the penalty I felt bad for myself, for the fans, family - not because of other stuff. You have to express yourself. For me, if you hide this stuff, you're not being yourself."

Portugal were ultimately eliminated by France in the quarter-finals of Euros following another penalty shootout. Just as he did against Slovenia, Ronaldo scored in the shootout, but Portugal were beaten 5-3. It marked the first major international tournament that Ronaldo, who struggled to make any sort of impact during the competition, failed to find the back of the net in.

headline: Man Utd make final transfer decision on Ben Chilwell after Chelsea encouraged talks
body: Chelsea are hoping to find a new club for Ben Chilwell before the transfer window closes on Friday night and Manchester United has looked to be an ideal candidate to offload the star to
Manchester United have decided against making a move for Chelsea's Ben Chilwell.

The Blues' Champions League winner has been made available for sale by the west London side after Enzo Maresca decided last season's vice-captain was not part of his plans. Chelsea's new boss has instead favoured Marc Cucurella and new signing Renato Veiga as his options to head into the 2024/25 campaign.

That has left Chilwell training away from the first team, in addition to a number of other players including Raheem Sterling. The Stamford Bridge stars have been the subject of conversations with the possibilty of a deal being made with Manchester United before the end of the transfer window.

United's depth on the left side of defence has already been tested in August with Luke Shaw being ruled out by a pre-season injury. Lisandro Martinez and Diogo Dalot having featured in the position in the opening Premier League matches.

The Independent reports that United have decided to excuse themselves from any move for Chilwell, with the figures involved in such a deal proving off-putting. Chelsea had offered their 27-year-old defender to United as executives debated the possibility of finding solutions for Chilwell, Sterling and Jadon Sancho.

Former Leicester star Chilwell is now running out of time to find a club before the closure of the transfer window. Maresca made it clear ahead of the Premier League season that his charge did not have a position in his system
"With Chilly it's quite clear," said Maresca. "I love the way he trains, I love the way he is but the problem is that he struggles with us a little bit to find his best position.

"When you train everyday and you don't get minutes, it's not good for them and it's not good for me because I need to make decisions. For some players, it's sometimes better to leave and to go somewhere to get minutes. We will see what happens, the transfer window is open and we will see what happens."

A move to Old Trafford may have been appealing to Chilwell, who has fond memories of visiting Old Trafford as a child. "I used to go to Man United games, funnily enough, with my dad, who supported them," he said last year.

"The first one, I can’t remember who it was against, but it was a Man United game. We always used to go to the Champions League ones after school, so it would have been a Champions League game at Old Trafford. That’s the first one I remember. Having your first one in the Champions League is pretty good.

"We used to go by train, we would have to take about four different trains straight from school, and just about make it for kick-off, then get about four different trains on the way home as well, get home for one o’clock in the morning, straight into school the next morning again, but they were brilliant memories."

headline: Cristiano Ronaldo makes retirement confession amid Man Utd 'unfinished business' claims
body: Cristiano Ronaldo is still going strong despite being on the verge of turning 40, and the Portugal superstar has revealed what he wants to achieve before calling it a day
Cristiano Ronaldo says he plans on playing for at least another two years amid talk of a sensational return to Manchester United.

The 39-year-old is well into the twilight of his incredible career - one that few footballers in history could ever hope to emulate. After his brace for Al Nassr against Al Feiha on Tuesday, Ronaldo is now just one strike away from reaching 900 career goals.

Speaking to former United team-mate Rio Ferdinand, Ronaldo admitted his main focus is on reaching quadruple figures, which suggests retirement plans aren't even being considered yet. "One thing that I've learned in the last few years is [to] enjoy the moment. Live the moment because you don't know what's going to happen tomorrow," he said on his UR Cristiano YouTube channel.
"I know I'm still looking good, I feel that I can still dribble, score goals, shoot, jump. The day that I start to feel that I can't produce anything I will pack by bags and go away."

Continuing, he boasted: "I scored 60 goals [last] season, but I didn't score in five games at the Euros and people ask 'What's going on? What's the problem?' [But] I scored 130 [goals for Portugal], I'm the [best goalscorer at international level] in the world's history.

"Soon I will [score] 900 [career goals], and after that I will beat 1,000. I want to reach it." Ferdinand asked him how old he reckoned he'd be by the time he reached the milestone, to which Ronaldo replied: "41? I don't know. This is why I told you I want to leave the present.
"But if I don't have injuries, this is the most important thing. I want [to reach 1,000 goals]. For me it's the best mark that I can have in football."

Ronaldo is statistically the highest competitive goalscorer in the history of football, with eternal rival Lionel Messi behind him on 838 goals, and Brazil legend Pele in third-place on 762. There are claims Pele scored over 1,000 goals, though his record is disputed as many of the goals were scored in non-competitive friendly and exhibition matches.

Poking fun at the three-time World Cup winner, Ronaldo told Ferdinand: "There is one difference [with my goals record]. All the goals that I scored, they have video. So I can prove that [they happened]."

Ronaldo recently claimed he plans to finish his career at Al-Nassr. "I don't know if I will retire soon, in two or three years, but probably I will retire here at Al-Nassr," he told Portuguese outlet Now. "I'm happy at this club. I feel good in this country too. I'm happy to play in Saudi Arabia and I want to continue."

Earlier this month, ex-United star Louis Saha tipped Ronaldo for a shock return to Old Trafford at some point in the future, citing the fact the five-time Ballon d'Or winner has "unfinished business" at the club following his acrimonious exit in 2022.
"Cristiano Ronaldo has the passion and dedication to return to Manchester United one day," Saha told TVSporten. "That could be as a coach or even a manager.

"His second spell didn’t end how everyone had hoped, and you can see why that frustrated him. He didn’t see the same formula and didn’t see the passion from young players that he had been used to seeing."
Ronaldo made 346 appearances for the Red Devils over two separate spells, scoring 145 goals. His second stint ended in disaster after he was dropped from the first team by new manager Erik ten Hag.
In response, Ronaldo slammed both the manager and the club in a now infamous interview with Piers Morgan. A few days later, his contract was terminated by mutual consent.

headline: Cristiano Ronaldo finally admits motivation for Saudi Arabia transfers in damning statement
body: Cristiano Ronaldo made the switch from Manchester United to Al Nassr in 2022, becoming the first star to jump to the Middle East, and he has now revealed the main reason for transfers to the country
Cristiano Ronaldo has revealed the main reason he knew others would follow him to the Saudi Pro League was the money on offer.

Ronaldo joined Al Nassr from Manchester United just before the 2022 World Cup, shocking the world of football with his switch to Saudi Arabia. It followed an explosive tell-all interview with Piers Morgan about his second spell at the Red Devils, which put him on a collision course with Erik ten Hag and ultimately saw him leave the club by mutual agreement.

Once it became apparent that he would not get a lucrative contract offer in Europe, Ronaldo joined Al Nassr in a move that sparked a massive influx of foreign talent into the Middle East. While the 39-year-old reiterated the respect he holds for Saudi football, Ronaldo revealed his motivation – and that of other players in the league – for going to Saudi and admitted that money is the "main reason" why it has attracted the stars it now boasts.

"Any place I play, I show my level,” Ronaldo revealed on his UR Cristiano YouTube channel. “I knew that there [Saudi Arabia] I would show my level as well. I will improve the league, and I knew that players would follow me."

The list of talent that followed Ronaldo to Saudi Arabia makes for astounding reading. The list of names is headlined by his former team-mate Karim Benzema, as well as the likes of N'Golo Kante, Sadio Mane, and Neymar, who upon his arrival stated: "Cristiano started all of this, and they called him crazy."

Ronaldo continued, referencing the financial incentives that are on offer in Saudi Arabia. "I knew that players would follow because, not only in financial terms, which is the main point you can say, but as well the culture of football," Ronaldo said.
"I knew the culture of Saudi football was nice because I had friends who played there before, Portuguese coaches were there.

"Of course, if you ask me: You expect so quickly for big stars would move there? - No. But, I expected the football would change because of me. I believe in myself, not only in football but in other areas as well."

According to multiple report, Al Nassr pay the Portuguese star £173million-a-year. That doesn't just include his salary, as his image rights and commercial deals also contribute to the figure. This vast amount breaks down into £3.6m-a-week, £514,000-a-day, and £21,400-an-hour.
Neymar is reportedly earning in the region of £2.5million-a-week at Al-Hilal, while former Manchester City winger Riyad Mahrez is said to be on around £750,000 a week at Al-Ahli.

Despite Ronaldo's admittance that the financial terms on offer are an undoubted motivation for moving, he felt little pressure being the first big name to take a leap into the league - something he proved last season as he netted a record-breaking 35 Saudi Pro League goals.

"To be honest there was zero pressure moving," Ronaldo added. "I didn’t have any pressure. I didn’t feel any pressure. Of course you have other issues. Does it make sense? Will it work out professionally? But to be honest, I felt free."

headline: Jadon Sancho 'reaches agreement' on Man Utd exit after Raheem Sterling swap talks
body: Jadon Sancho is set to leave Manchester United, having been left out of both of their squads in the Premier League this season, with Chelsea having been one of his suitors
Jadon Sancho has agreed a deal to join Juventus on loan, appearing to put an end to Raheem Sterling's links to Manchester United.

Sancho is free to leave Old Trafford this summer, despite mending his differences with boss Erik ten Hag. The winger has been left out of both squads for United's Premier League games so far this season.
With the Englishman having no future in Manchester - Juve and Chelsea emerged as potential suitors. The Blues' interest was contingent on United agreeing to a swap deal involving Sterling.

The Chelsea man is in a similar situation to Sancho and has been frozen out by boss Enzo Maresca. But it now appears that Sancho has rejected the chance to join the London side and is instead set to leave the Premier League.

According to L'Equipe, Sancho has approached Juve to seal a loan move to the Serie A giants. Juve are said to have agreed on many of the details with United, which will contain an option to buy clause.

That clause will have 'very low conditions' to be activated though, making it likely Sancho will ultimately be bidding a permanent farewell to United this summer. Signing Sancho means the Italian giants have brought in one of their top summer targets.

The 24-year-old had also been heavily linked with a move to PSG, possibly as part of a swap deal involving Manuel Ugarte. But the French giants dropped their interest in Sancho, with Ugarte set to move to United in a straightforward transfer.

After leaving him out of the opening day win over Fulham, Ten Hag pointed to a recent illness Sancho had. But it was ultimately understood to be a selection decision, with the United boss warning the winger he had to fight for his place.

"First of all we need squad depth and we need it this season to be survival of the fittest. I can only put 20 players in the squad, I have to make choices and in the week, he had an ear infection but he was not 100 per cent fit," Ten Hag said.

"He could play but if we had the choices, we preferred to put other players on the bench but that will change in the season as we have to rotate, because we can't play so many games the same. You see how important the subs are and you see it is about balance.

"Sometimes it is frustrating about the team, the club and there will be more players in this position. We expect them to fight for the club, as we have so many games to play for the club. Everyone will get their minutes and then they have to prove it."
Sancho was also left out of the squad for the defeat to Brighton on Saturday. Ten Hag again warned the former England international that he needed to improve his performances in training.

headline: Manuel Ugarte shows he's ready for £50m Man Utd transfer with Darwin Nunez comment
body: Manuel Ugarte is set to complete his £50.7million transfer to Manchester United and the midfielder has shown he has the thick skin required to thrive in the Premier League
New Manchester United signing Manuel Ugarte looks fully prepared to shrug off any flak coming his way - and he has Liverpool's Darwin Nunez for inspiration.

The Uruguay anchor is on the verge of sealing a move to Old Trafford from Paris Saint-Germain for a £50.7million as he follows fellow Copa America finalist Nunez to England's top flight. Although Ugarte will be among friends in his new home, he's proved he can stand his ground single-handedly after seeing how Nunez has coped with significant criticism online.

Showing resilience akin to Liverpool's record signing, 23-year-old Ugarte is ready for the mental challenges of the Premier League. Speaking about the personal attacks players face on social media earlier this summer, Ugarte highlighted Nunez's struggles and how that's influenced his own approach.

"For example, Darwin [Nunez] had moments where he was killed badly, and that is also something that has a lot of merit when you see where he is today," he told Channel 10 in Uruguay. "You have to be in the right head to get to where he got to with all the damage he got."

Ugarte, who is understood to have undergone his United medical on Wednesday, admitted that footballers are "very exposed" online due to their fame. He's taken a step back from social media in recent years, however, acknowledging that "not everyone's going to like you."

And while he may be a self-sufficient talent in what he brings to United's squad, Ugarte is all about the success of the group. United fans may take to one particular comment about defending those around him, a role United need sorely in order to get the most out of a misfiring attack.

"When I see a team-mate get hit, I sometimes feel like the next day it could be me because people kill you the way they put you up there," he continued. "The best thing is to surround yourself with people you love and trust, and not give the ball to the net, because that's how the net is nowadays."

Despite making a name for himself in Portuguese football and enhancing his profile at PSG, the midfield maestro is set to face even greater scrutiny at United. But while Ugarte maintains a tough exterior in the court of public opinion, he conceded he's not immune to criticism.

"I say this with humility, there are people who don't know anything about football and have an opinion, and maybe that comment has a lot of likes and it seems to be 'true,'" he continued. "I think it's something I handle quite well; but if something happens to me where everyone kills me, it's not good."

headline: Man Utd's £200m spending spree puts pressure on Erik ten Hag to achieve top target
body: Manuel Ugarte's imminent arrival at Manchester United will take their summer spend to £200m, making them stronger to re-establish themselves in the top four - and leaving boss Erik ten Hag with no excuses for falling short
Manuel Ugarte's imminent confirmation as a Manchester United player will take the club's summer transfer spend to around £200million.
Sir Jim Ratcliffe and his new United football executive team have delivered Erik ten Hag the signings he wanted as he bids to take the club back into the top four of the Premier League.
After last season's worst-ever Premier League finish of eighth, the new regime at United have reacted in the strongest possible way, with Ugarte set to be their fifth summer signing.
The Uruguay midfielder, signed from Paris Saint-Germain, will join Leny Yoro, Joshua Zirkzee, Matthijs De Ligt and Noussair Mazraoui as the latest addition to Ten Hag's improved squad.
United may have stumbled to a fifth successive Premier League defeat to Brighton last weekend, but there is feeling of optimism over the long-term picture following the club's summer business.
Put simply, Ten Hag's squad – with incomings and outgoings – is better equipped to re-establish United as a top-four club and continue the rebuild towards becoming title challengers once again.
But that improvement brings with it expectations, not least on Ten Hag, who knows he can have no excuses for failing to deliver this season after being backed by his bosses in the transfer market.

This summer, Ten Hag has got the players he wanted, two of whom he has worked with previously at Ajax, in De Ligt and Mazraoui, so cannot claim he has not been supported in the strengthening of his personnel.
United's familiar defensive vulnerability may have returned late on to condemn them to a 2-1 defeat at Brighton, but there has been no sense of panic within the club, despite that early setback.

The belief is the arrival of Ugarte will give United greater solidity and security in midfield, allowing Kobbie Mainoo to push further forward, with Yoro – currently injured - De Ligt and Mazraoui offering similar qualities in defence, and Zirkzee bringing a different dimension to the attack, with his ability to drop deep and play in a range of positions across the forward line.

Key to securing the new arrivals – against a backdrop of restricted spending because of the Premier League's profit and sustainability rules (PSR) – has been United's shrewd business when it comes to selling players this summer, something at which they have been lamentable in recent years.

In selling Mason Greenwood, Donny van de Beek, Aaron Wan-Bissaka, Facundo Pellistri, Willy Kambwala, Alvaro Fernandez, Hannibal Mejbri and Scott McTominay, United are set to recoup close to £100m, which will go a long way to offsetting their £200m outlay and ensuring they comply with PSR.

Sunday's visit to Old Trafford of arch rivals Liverpool – who have won both of their opening games under new boss Arne Slot – represents another huge test for United and Ten Hag so early in the season. Defeat would increase the pressure on the United boss, who remained in charge, only after the club's hierarchy had interviewed other candidates but ultimately decided to stick with Ten Hag.
United's impressive work at rebuilding their squad with younger players with long-term value is aimed at making the team more consistent in the years ahead, irrespective of who is in charge.

Ten Hag knows as much, which is also why he is acutely aware he cannot afford to fall short in the coming weeks, particularly with former England boss Gareth Southgate, a known favourite of Ineos, waiting in the wings.

headline: Matthijs de Ligt makes 'difficult' admission in response to Man Utd's big challenge
body: Matthijs de Ligt has joined Manchester United from Bayern Munich this summer and the Dutch defender has opened up about the "difficult" journey the club faces to get back to the top
Matthijs de Ligt has warned it is "going to be difficult" for Manchester United to start challenging for the Premier League title again.

De Ligt joined United from Bayern Munich earlier this month, with the defender one of the first new signings under Sir Jim Ratcliffe who has taken full control of football operations after purchasing a stake in the club from the Glazers.

Despite United spending over £200million on De Ligt, Joshua Zirkzee, Leny Yoro, Noussair Mazraoui and impending arrival Manuel Ugarte so far this summer, the Dutchman admits his new club will need to be patient as they plot their way back to the top.

"We want to get United back to where they belong," De Ligt told Optus. "That's at the top of the Premier League and I think if you go from here to here [gestures with his hands], then it's going to be difficult.

"But if you do it step by step, and I feel already we're making a lot of good steps and everyone within the club is really excited, motivated and hungry. If we can make every training like that we feel like a better team in every session, we have a really good squad and can go far in every competition."

De Ligt also reflected on his first few weeks at United, admitting the lure of linking up with manager Erik ten Hag again played a big part in his decision to join. "It's an amazing experience. It's a really big club," he added.

"Obviously from the outside you know it's a big club, but when you're in here, you feel the love from the fans, the atmosphere in the stadium and the professionalism in training and I've been really enjoying it until now.

"He [Ten Hag] made me captain at Ajax, also in my time at Ajax he gave me a lot of confidence, a lot of motivation to lead the team, so this summer, when United came for me... it made it really easy for me to get to the Premier League first of all and secondly, to the biggest club in England.
"For me, it was a really easy choice to make. I actually grew up watching the 2007/2008 Champions League when they won it, Cristiano scored the goal and they had such amazing teams.

"Van der Sar, the Dutchman, was obviously the goalkeeper and when I was younger Ajax was my home team, my dream always, but I grew up watching Cristiano getting bigger and bigger and he played for United, so I always watched a little bit of their games."

headline: Raheem Sterling urged to retire after Chelsea fallout - despite Man Utd bid
body: Raheem Sterling has been exiled by new Chelsea boss Enzo Maresca and Vinnie Jones has suggested he should retire, despite Manchester United being interested in the winger
Former Chelsea star Vinnie Jones has suggested Raheem Sterling should consider retirement after he was exiled by Enzo Maresca.

Maresca has been tasked with cutting down Chelsea's huge squad since replacing Mauricio Pochettino and the likes of Conor Gallagher, Ian Maatsen and Malang Sarr have all been offloaded by the Blues in recent weeks.

Chelsea are also looking to get rid of Sterling, Ben Chilwell, Trevoh Chalobah, Romelu Lukaku, Kepa Arrizabalaga and Armando Broja before the transfer window slams shut. Although Manchester United are in talks with Chelsea over a swap deal involving Sterling and Jadon Sancho, Jones believes the winger should contemplate walking away from the sport altogether.

"Sterling not being in the squad was a little eyebrow raiser," he told the Daily Mail. "Everything comes to an end though and he's done all right." Jones retired from football in 1998 at the age of 34, with the footballer going on to forge a successful acting career.

And he believes Sterling could follow suit and retire early, adding: "He scored a few goals, and he might do a job for someone else, but he's had a fantastic career and if I was him I might think about going into something else.

"He must be financially set up for life. So, go and enjoy life. He's given the sport a lot in terms of England fans and at Liverpool and Man City. He's given a lot of fans a lot of enjoyment over the years and I don't like seeing top players like him drift down through the leagues.

"'I hope he doesn't do that. I had a journalist once say that I would end up back at Wealdstone. So I spent my whole career proving him wrong. What they've got is a massive chequebook, and they're desperate to get back to the days under Roman Abramovich, aren't they?

"I think you'll see quite a few of them, sort of either left out or moving on in the last week of the transfer window, as that's a b****y big squad to pay wages to. With 40 odd players, I don't know how that's going to pan out."
Sterling joined Chelsea from Manchester City for £47.5million in 2022 and he has scored 19 goals in 81 appearances for the Blues across all competitions.

headline: Carabao Cup third round draw – Ball numbers, rule change, how Bowl 1 and 2 are split
body: The format of the Carabao Cup's third-round draw has undergone a makeover, while the schedule itself is also in for change to accommodate those teams featuring in Europe
English football fans will be treated to a new-look draw for the third round of the Carabao Cup tonight.

The Premier League's elite will join the competition in the next stage of the tournament, once the remaining second-round fixtures have been played out on Wednesday. Following the conclusion of the last midweek matches, a total of 32 balls will be drawn from two bowls at the City Ground to determine who will face who in the third round.

Manchester City, Arsenal, Liverpool and Aston Villa all enter the mix as Champions League participants, as will Europa League contenders Manchester United and Tottenham, along with Chelsea, who are in the Conference League. However, the six teams competing in the Champions League and Europa League will be drawn from a separate bowl (Bowl 1) as a result of changes to those competitions this season.

The expansion of those tournament to 36-team 'league phase' schedules means more congested fixture lists, and those teams will be kept apart in the third round to avoid fixture clashes. Chelsea - who beat Servette 2-0 in the first leg of their Conference League play-off - will be selected from Bowl 2 given their European campaign proper won't start until October.

Prior to Nottingham Forest 's home game against Newcastle on Wednesday, a pre-draw to determine home and away status for the six clubs from Bowl 1 will take place. After the conclusion of that match, selectors will then alternate between Bowl 1 and Bowl 2 to decide the fates of those six clubs competing in Europe.

Only Bowl 2 will be used to determine the remaining 10 third-round fixtures given Bowl 1 will be empty at that point. Organisers will also do away with the northern and southern sections from the third round onwards, paving the way for cross-country trips aplenty.

headline: Man Utd hold Ivan Toney transfer talks in last-minute attempt to hijack Chelsea deal
body: Manchester United are closing in on Paris Saint-Germain midfielder Manuel Ugarte but it's also been claimed that the top brass at Old Trafford have discussed a deal for Ivan Toney
Manchester United have reportedly held talks over a potential swoop for Ivan Toney ahead of Friday's transfer deadline.
The Red Devils are close to wrapping up a deal for Manuel Ugarte, who will follow Joshua Zirkzee, Leny Yoro, Matthijs de Ligt and Noussair Mazraoui through the door.
And it has now been claimed that Manchester United have also held exploratory talks over a deal for Toney, who is expected to move on from Brentford in the coming days.

That's according to a new report from The Evening Standard, who believe that initial talks have been held between the top brass at Old Trafford and Brentford over a deal for the 28-year-old England star.

United have been linked with Toney previously and signing a new No.9 was their priority heading into the summer. But Zirkzee was signed from Bologna to compete with Rasmus Hojlund, who signed for big money last summer.
Toney has Premier League nous, though, and notched 20 league goals during the 2022/23 campaign before he was banned for eight months for breaching betting rules.

While Toney has failed to land a big move yet, his situation is an intriguing one heading into the final days of the window. He is reported to have a lucrative offer from Saudi Arabia on the table, while Chelsea have also held talks over a potential switch.

The Blues have been active this summer and remain in the market for a new striker. They have been linked with both Toney and Victor Osimhen, who is seeking a move away from Napoli, though it's highly unlikely they would attempt to push through deals for both.

Toney has not been selected for either of Brentford's opening Premier League games amid interest in his services, but Thomas Frank was giving little away ahead of Wednesday night's Carabao Cup tie with Colchester United.
The Dane said: “I’m always happy when the window shuts. Then I don’t have to talk about ifs and buts and when and maybes, about a lot of players and of course Ivan. It’s all about Ivan!”

When he was then asked if a deal for Toney was close, Frank added: “Very good question. I actually haven’t asked about that in the last two or three days, so I don’t know actually. He trained well all week with a good attitude.”

headline: Manchester United show new ruthless transfer approach with TWO Hannibal Mejbri clauses
body: Man Utd's insistence in two key clauses in Hannibal Mejbri's move to Burnley will maximise their financial return from the deal and are indicative a new hard-line approach in the transfer market under Sir Jim Ratcliffe
Manchester United's improved performance in the transfer market under the new Ineos regime has been underlined by Hannibal Mejbri's permanent switch to Burnley.
The Tunisia international, who would have struggled for game time at United, has joined the Clarets on a four-year deal worth an initial £5.4million, rising to a potential total fee of £9.4m.

The decent fee helps towards United's compliance with the Premier League's profit and sustainability rules, given their current transfer outlay this summer currently stands at £200m, including the £50m arrival of Manuel Ugarte, which could be confirmed later today

But the detail that shows how United have got their act together under Sir Jim Ratcliffe's new football executive team, lead by CEO Omar Berrada and sporting director Dan Ashworth is in the clauses inserted within the Mejbri deal.

As well as the add-ons, which could ultimately total £4m, United have managed to include two key clauses within the deal for Mejbri – an initial 50 per cent sell-on of any future transfer fee Burnley receive for Mejbri, as well as matching rights.

The two clauses show how United, who have struggled to maximise the fees for players they sell on in recent years, have adopted a more clinical and strategic approach to such a key part of of recruitment, particularly with profit and sustainability rules restricting the spending of clubs.

United's new approach to buying and selling stems from the conclusion of the forensic audit undertaken by Ratcliffe's right-hand man, Sir Dave Brailsford, and also overseen by fellow senior Ineos advisors Jean-Claude Blanc and Rob Nevin.

The audit looked at the last five years of player recruitment at United, not just with regard to incomings, but also outgoings, with the club's inability to recoup decent fees – something at which local rivals Manchester City excel – seen as major area for improvement.

The Mejbri deal is one that illustrates United's more ruthless approach to moving players on for significant fees, something the club are also doing with another midfielder, Scott McTominay, who is set to join Napoli before Friday's 11pm transfer deadline.
In addition to Mejbri and McTominay, United have already raised £25.2m from the sale of Mason Greenwood to Marseille, a deal which also included a significant sell-on clause.

Funds have also been generated with the departures of Donny van de Beek, Aaron Wan-Bissaka, Facundo Pellistri, Willy Kambwala and Alvaro Fernandez, with a total of around £60m raised from player sales so far this summer.

With further potential departures including Jadon Sancho and Victor Lindelof, United could raise close to £100m from player sales, a figure they have come nowhere near to reaching in the past decade, one which underlines the pace of change brought in by the new regime in charge.

headline: Sofyan Amrabat offered Premier League transfer lifeline after flopping at Man Utd
body: Fiorentina midfielder Sofyan Amrabat spent last season on loan at Manchester United and both Everton and Fenerbahce are interested in signing him before the transfer window closes
Everton have reportedly made an approach for Sofyan Amrabat, with the Fiorentina midfielder's future uncertain following his loan spell at Manchester United.

Amrabat spent last season on loan at Old Trafford, but he made just 17 starts for United across all competitions. The 28-year-old did finish his loan spell on a high, though, as he played a full 90 minutes in United's FA Cup final win over Manchester City.

And Amrabat admitted after the final that he was keen to stay at United, telling Ziggo Sport: "Do I already know what I'm going to do next year? No. We are going to talk. Staying is certainly an option.

"Look, I think it has been a very difficult season. For Manchester United it needs to be much better, and also for me personally. I have always remained calm and trained very hard. Ultimately, that patience has been rewarded.

"We are going to talk. Manchester United are the biggest club in the world, so who wouldn't want to play football here? But all parties have to be happy with each other, so we will sit down now and see what happens."

However, United are set to sign Manuel Ugarte instead, with the Red Devils forking out an initial £42.2million for the Paris Saint-Germain midfielder. He will sign a five-year contract, while PSG have inserted a 10 percent sell-on clause into the deal.

Amrabat, meanwhile, has returned to Fiorentina and featured in their first three games this season. However, Fabrizio Romano - via the Metro - is reporting that Everton have made an approach to bring him back to the Premier League.

Everton are not the only club interested in signing Amrabat, with Jose Mourinho's Fenerbahce also in talks to bring him to Turkey. It is claimed Fenerbahce have offered to pay a €2m (£1.6m) loan fee and a €12m (£10m) obligation to buy, but Fiorentina believe he is worth more.

Negotiations are continuing over Amrabat's future, with Fiorentina having already signed fellow Morocco international Amir Richardson as a potential replacement. Richardson joined from Reims earlier this month for a fee of around €9m (£7.5m).

headline: Chelsea's strongest XI with Jadon Sancho and Ivan Toney completing chaotic window
body: Chelsea have enjoyed a busy summer so far and the Blues are looking to finalise the signings of Brentford striker Ivan Toney and Manchester United winger Jadon Sancho before the window closes
Chelsea have been very busy in the transfer market so far this summer, with plenty of incomings and outgoings.

The likes of Pedro Neto, Joao Felix and Kiernan Dewsbury-Hall have all made big money moves to Stamford Bridge, while Conor Gallagher, Ian Maatsen, Lewis Hall and Omari Hutchinson have departed for significant fees.
However, several more deals could be completed before the transfer window slams shut, with Chelsea in talks with Manchester United over a swap deal involving Raheem Sterling and Jadon Sancho.
The Blues have also made a late bid to sign Brentford striker Ivan Toney, a proven Premier League goalscorer who would likely lead the line for new boss Enzo Maresca ahead of Nicolas Jackson.

Maresca has made no secret of his desire to sign a new striker, admitting earlier this month: "If we have the chance to bring in a nine that can help us and make the difference, then we are going to try. Otherwise, we are okay."

Chelsea do have a number of options out wide, but Sancho could feature on the right if he joins from United. Neto looks likely to start on the left once he gets fully up to speed, with Mykhaylo Mudryk and Noni Madueke providing support.

Cole Palmer has been most effective for Chelsea in the No.10 role and is likely to start there ahead of Felix and Christopher Nkunku, although the England international has also featured on the right.
Enzo Fernandez and Moises Caicedo have already been established as Maresca's first-choice pairing in midfield, with Dewsbury-Hall and Romeo Lavia among the other options at Chelsea's disposal.

In defence, Maresca has opted for a back four of Malo Gusto, Wesley Fofana, Levi Colwill and Marc Cucurella in his first two league games in charge and looks likely to continue with them, particularly with captain Reece James currently sidelined with an injury.

Benoit Badiashile, Axel Disasi and new signing Tosin Adarabioyo are among Maresca's other defensive options, with the manager looking to get rid of Ben Chilwell and Trevoh Chalobah before the window closes.

headline: Man Utd attackers would have six words to say about Raheem Sterling joining from Chelsea
body: With Raheem Sterling potentially heading to Manchester United before the window shuts, one ex-Premier League star thinks Erik ten Hag's attackers will all be thinking the same thing
Troy Deeney believes Manchester United players would be keen to learn from Raheem Sterling if he does arrive from Chelsea.

The ex-England international has been banished by Blues manager Enzo Maresca, who has even taken his No. 7 shirt and given it to new signing Pedro Neto. Sterling, 29, is currently in the wilderness at Cobham, where he is joined by the likes of Ben Chilwell and many others in training away from the first team.

However, Chelsea and United are reportedly in talks to perform a blockbuster swap deal which could see Jadon Sancho and Sterling trade places. While Sancho has agreed a truce with Erik ten Hag after their public fallout last year, the ex-Borussia Dortmund forward has not featured for the Red Devils since he missed the crucial penalty in United's Community Shield loss to Manchester City.

He has been left out of United's squad for the first two matches against Fulham and Brighton and Hove Albion, as Marcus Rashford, Amad Diallo, Antony, Alejandro Garnacho and new signing Joshua Zirkzee have been preferred. If Sterling was to join United, ex-Watford captain Deeney believes the United players will all be left thinking the same thing.

Speaking on Sky Sports, Deeney said: "Those guys will look at Raheem, see that he’s won it at [Manchester] City, see what he’s done at Liverpool, see what he’s done at the international stage and think ‘right, I can learn off that’.”
He also added: "(Right) now, he’s better than everything they’ve got there. He’d give more of a leadership role to the likes Garnacho and Amad.
"United fans will probably look at it as an improvement. Because, at the moment when I watch United, I thought they did OK at the weekend. They lacked one or two bits.
"If they get Luke Shaw back at left-back, that adds a completely different dynamic. And they need a striker, which is why I’m baffled they not going for Ivan Toney.

"That’d be a quick fix, like the (Robin) van Persie one, you just slot him in and it works. And right now, they need a winger. I don’t think Marcus is delivering. The other guys… Antony’s nothing. I don’t mean that disrespectfully, but they are not offering anything to the level that they should do for a team like Man United.”

United have already spent close to £200million this summer. They are on the cusp of signing Paris Saint-Germain midfielder Manuel Ugarte for around £52m. He will be the fifth player to arrive at the club after Matthijs de Ligt, Zirkzee, Noussair Mazraoui and 18-year-old central defender Leny Yoro.

United have a tricky test up next off the back of their defeat at Brighton as they host Sterling's former club Liverpool on Sunday. Arne Slot's side have began the campaign faultlessly and will open up a six-point gap on the Red Devils if they overcome them at Old Trafford.

headline: Dan Ashworth stays away from £51m transfer talks to prioritise three Man Utd deals
body: Manchester United are close to completing a deal for Manuel Ugarte but sporting director Dan Ashworth has been focusing on different matters ahead of the transfer deadline
Dan Ashworth did not travel to France to thrash out a deal for Manuel Ugarte in order to oversee a number of Manchester United outgoings.

The Red Devils have finally struck an agreement with Paris Saint-Germain for Ugarte, 23, after weeks of negotiations and the Uruguay international is expected to be United's fifth and final summer signing shortly.

It has since emerged that technical director Jason Wilcox flew out with Matt Hargreaves, United's director of negotiations, to iron out the final details on a deal which will see Erik ten Hag land his top midfield target in a deal which could reach £51million.
But United's new sporting director remained in Manchester to finalise exits for Scott McTominay, Hannibal Mejbri and Jadon Sancho, according to The Mail.
McTominay has been the subject of interest from clubs in the Premier League and overseas this summer and the midfielder is now poised to join Napoli for a £26m fee.

Hannibal, another central midfielder, is also on his way out. The 21-year-old has dropped down to the Championship to join Burnley as they chase an instant return to the top-flight in a deal worth around £9.4m.

And while there is currently no agreement in place for Sancho to depart Old Trafford, there is interest from Chelsea and Juventus - and Ashworth is set to take the lead on negotiating any potential exit.
It emerged on Tuesday that United and Chelsea had entered into talks over a potential swap deal which would see Raheem Sterling join United with Sancho moving in the opposite direction.

Enzo Maresca made it clear last week that Sterling had no future at Stamford Bridge after the winger was omitted from the team that lost 2-0 to Manchester City on the opening weekend of the new Premier League season.

The Blues boss delivered the news in a press conference, where he was asked if his handling of the situation with Sterling had been brutal. He responded: "Brutal? I don't think so. I try to be honest. I can repeat again if it's not clear: I spoke with Raheem before the City game. I said he is going to struggle to get minutes with us and this is the reason why he is out of the squad.

"With Chilly, I said he is a lovely guy, but he is going to struggle because of his position. He is going to struggle. If you define this as brutal, it's up to you to decide. For me, it's not brutal, it's just honest."

headline: Oasis' Noel Gallagher washed Man Utd legend's car – and got rewarded with Penguin biscuits
body: Noel and Liam Gallagher stunned the world this week by announcing Oasis' comeback, but the famous musician has a humble past, which saw him wash a Manchester United star's car
Oasis icon Noel Gallagher may be one of Manchester City's most famous fans, but he once found himself washing a Manchester United legend's car.

Noel, along with his brother Liam, made headlines on Tuesday by announcing that Oasis were to reunite 15 years after the band split up. The Gallaghers are famously two of the mouthiest men in rock and roll. However, according to ex-United forward Brian McClair, Noel didn't even utter a word when, as a young man, he popped round his house.

The songsmith may be one of the UK's most successful, and wealthiest, musicians, but that wasn't always the case. In a far cry from the Champagne Supernova lifestyle Noel later found himself living, McClair revealed that the guitarist and his brother would help out a friend with his car washing service.

Speaking on the Sport Social Network podcast in 2023, the ex-United and Celtic player lifted the lid on the curious tale. He relayed the awkward encounter with Noel and explained just how a future member of rock royalty ended up giving his car a valet – and how he found himself owning a very rare piece of Oasis memorabilia.

According to McClair, Noel became acquainted with the United squad through a man named Paul Ashby, a friend who shared Gallagher's love for Manchester City. Ashby used to wash the City players' cars but then decided to take his business to the red half of the city.

After approaching Sir Alex Ferguson at United's old Cliff training ground, with Paul offering to clean the Red Devils players' vehicles too, he found himself needing a hand. Shortly after building a rapport with the United squad, Paul began to invite the players to his home to get their cars cleaned, and it's there where Liam and Noel began helping him with the valeting service.

McClair told the story of how Noel arrived at his house one day to assist with the cleaning. However to McClair's astonishment, the usually vocal Oasis and High-Flying Birds star barley uttered a single word.

McClair said: "Noel came to the house one day to clean the car and he never said a f***ing word." The show's host was shocked and interjected: "That's not like him is it?" Which prompted McClair to respond: "Not a thing, that's what I'm saying."

Despite Noel's silence, he did accept McClair's wife's offer of coffee and chocolate biscuits. McClair added: "Then the missus made him a coffee, and brought out some chocolate biscuits." That included Penguins and a few other household favourites such as Gold Bars and Blue Ribbands.

Some might say Noel was underpaid – but he didn't seem to mind as McClair recalls him being polite while he was at his house. However, he recalled that sharing his gratitude was the only time Noel opened his mouth. The 60-year-old said: "He said thanks for that but that's all he said in the 45 mins to an hour period he was there."

In an amazing twist, McClair revealed he received a priceless nice parting gift – an early Oasis demo tape that he still has to this day. The former Scotland international also recalls how he was impressed with what he heard, adding: "Paul gave me a demo of Oasis, and I said to him, 'ah it's pretty good that'. I've still got it, it's a copy of the original of them doing their early songs."
McClair enjoyed a trophy-laden spell with Motherwell, Celtic and United. He scored 202 goals in that time and retired from the game in 1999.

headline: 'I left Man Utd without talking to Erik ten Hag - I felt unloved and knew what he'd say'
body: Former Manchester United midfielder Andreas Pereira previously opened up on how he avoided Erik ten Hag to seal a move away from the club
Andreas Pereira previously admitted that he dodged Erik ten Hag to seal his Manchester United exit after feeling 'unloved' at the club.
The Brazilian midfielder left Old Trafford in the summer of 2022 after loan spells at Valencia, Granada, Lazio and Flamengo to join Premier League side Fulham for £8million.

Despite question marks surrounding his future potential, the 28-year-old has cemented a starting place in the Fulham line-up, making 23 goal contributions in 84 total appearances - and had even reportedly caught the eye of Chelsea this summer with his performances for the Cottagers.

Speaking earlier this year, the Brazilian admitted that he refused to talk to Ten Hag - who had coached him at PSV - in order to push through a move away from Manchester so he could play regular first-team football. The Dutchman had just been appointed as Ole Gunnar Solskjaer's permanent successor when Pereira was returning from his fourth loan spell away from the club.
Ten Hag was still assessing his squad when Pereira took the decision away from him by angling for a transfer, fearing he'd only be a bit-part player.

He told Vibe with Five: "This was when I came back to England [after my loan in Brazil]. Erik ten Hag, he worked at PSV when I was 16 years old. Before leaving for United, the [PSV] president and Erik ten Hag came to speak to me and my dad and said, ‘Look everything is set up for you at PSV, if you stay here you’re going to play in the first team’. But I’d just been to United and spoke with Fergie. I was like, ‘I’m going to United’.

"That’s why I didn’t want to speak to Erik because I knew him and I knew that, at the time, it was always a conversation, like, ‘Andreas, stay here. You’re not going to play every game, maybe one game in every three, you’ll be around the squad’. That’s not what I wanted, I wanted to play."

The midfielder, who made just 75 appearances for United despite coming through the club's youth ranks in 2014, admitted he had reservations about leaving the Red Devils but took the plunge to return to Brazil where he could earn the 'love' he deserved.

Pereira said: "Leaving United, you’re like, ‘Am I really going to do this? Am I sure?’ In the end, you’re never 100 per cent sure, really. Sometimes you think stay and have another go. Other times, you have to leave.

"I wanted to play, after COVID, I wanted to play. I was going crazy, wanting to play in the Premier League. I wanted to show that I was good enough, I was very close to joining Everton and suddenly my father called me and said, ‘Andreas, you never played in Brazil, you’re Brazilian’.

"I was like, ‘Where do we go then?’ The president of Flamengo jokingly called my dad and said, ‘If he wants to come, he can come’. Everyone at United said, ‘You’re crazy, you’ll stay in Brazil, you’ll never come back to Europe’. Everyone in my family wanted me to come [to Brazil] but they were like, ‘No, what are you doing?’

headline: Man Utd made Manuel Ugarte breakthrough after 'mending bridges' with his trusted ally
body: Manuel Ugarte is set to complete his move from Paris Saint-Germain to Manchester United, with the midfielder becoming the second player represented by Jorge Mendes to move to Old Trafford this summer
Manchester United are set to confirm the signing of Manuel Ugarte from Paris Saint-Germain, having successfully 'mended bridges' with his agent Jorge Mendes.

Ugarte will become United's fifth signing of the summer after Joshua Zirkzee, Leny Yoro, Matthjis de Ligt and Noussair Mazraoui, with the Red Devils forking out an initial £42.2million for the 23-year-old midfielder.

PSG have a 10 per cent sell-on clause, while Ugarte will put pen to paper on a five-year deal. The Uruguay international will be the second player represented by Mendes to join United this summer, with Yoro also working with his Gestifute agency.

Mendes' most high-profile client was, of course, United legend Cristiano Ronaldo and he helped broker the deals that saw the forward join the club in 2003 and then return in 2021. However, Ronaldo's second stint at Old Trafford was a tumultuous one and ended when his deal was terminated following an explosive interview with Piers Morgan.

Ronaldo's acrimonious exit reportedly caused a falling out with Mendes after he was unable to secure him a move to another European club. The pair officially cut ties, with Ronaldo's subsequent move to Saudi Arabian club Al-Nassr not negotiated by Mendes.

According to the Daily Mail, Mendes' relationship with United was 'more than a little strained' as a result of the Ronaldo fallout, but the deals for Ugarte and Yoro are a clear indicator that it is 'water under the bridge'.

The Ugarte deal was finalised after United's technical director Jason Wilcox and director of player negotiations Matt Hargreaves flew to France on Monday to hash out the details with PSG, with Mendes also present.

Despite Mendes' professional split with Ronaldo, the super-agent has insisted the pair still have a "great personal relationship". Mendes said: "How do I see this phase of his life? Cristiano will always be in my heart.

"He is a special player and a special person for me. If I, a few years ago, thought that I could have a player with half the value of Cristiano, I would sign for less! And all of us Portuguese should be proud to have had and still have a player like him.
"I've always said it and I'll say it all my life: he was and is the best player in the entire history of world football! I don't have the slightest doubt, even compared to others."

headline: opinionRaheem Sterling has key trait Man Utd are lacking as Jadon Sancho swap deal discussed
body: Manchester United and Chelsea are holding talks over a sensational swap deal involving Raheem Sterling and Jadon Sancho, with both players having fallen out of favour at their clubs

Peter Beardsley is the only player to have worn the shirts of Manchester United, Liverpool and Manchester City - so Raheem Sterling would be following in hallowed footsteps should he get to realise his childhood dream of moving to Old Trafford.

‌Sterling has been told in no uncertain terms that he is surplus to requirements at Chelsea - and with Jadon Sancho still out in the cold in Manchester despite agreeing a truce with United boss Erik ten Hag, it has been suggested that a swap deal makes sense for both clubs.
Ironically, Sterling has confessed to being a United fan when he was growing up in Wembley, while Sancho loved the Chelsea team of Didier Drogba and Frank Lampard when he was a boy in South London.

‌But while the notion of the two former England team-mates trading places has a nice whiff of romance about it, for both Sir Jim Ratcliffe and Todd Boehly any deal will come down purely to the bottom line.

It might take Sterling some time to win over the United fans given his past at Anfield and the Etihad. But given Ratcliffe has already taken chief executive Omar Berrada and technical director Jason Wilcox from City, it appears local rivalries aren't being allowed to get in the way of business.

‌The fact that Sterling has failed to score in any of his 26 games against United for Liverpool, City or Chelsea might also help his cause! United’s first two games of the Premier League season has seen Ten Hag ask Bruno Fernandes and Mason Mount rotate in the role of deep-lying striker.
It’s fair to say, the plan hasn’t got the best out of either midfielder. It was only when Joshua Zirkzee came off the bench to score the winner against Fulham that United started to really threaten.‌

And in the 2-1 defeat at Brighton on Saturday, both players were substituted. United have got no shortage of talent in the wide areas, with Marcus Rashford, Alejandro Garnacho and Amad Diallo. Don’t forget, Ten Hag also has £95million winger Antony at his disposal.

‌But Sterling showed during his prime years under Pep Guardiola that he has the kind of versatility that Ten Hag needs. The 29-year-old operated on both flanks under the City boss, sometimes being asked to hold his position out wide to stretch opponents and in other games being used as an inverted winger with the freedom to cut inside.

‌It could even be argued that Sterling was at his very best when he was deployed in the ‘false nine’ position that is currently proving such a conundrum for Ten Hag while striker Rasmus Hojlund is injured.

In Guardiola’s first season at the Etihad, he managed just 10 goals. As he continued to develop his game under the Catalan, those numbers leapt to 23, 25 and 31 in the next three seasons. Even in Sterling’s final year at City, when it became clear he would be leaving, he managed to find the net 17 times.

That kind of adaptability and goal threat is just what Ten Hag needs right now - and a swap deal that includes Sancho would also enable the United boss to find a cure for one of his biggest headaches.

‌Where Sancho fits in at Stamford Bridge is another matter given the sheer number of players that they are trying to sell. But what is clear is that the 24-year-old needs a clean break from United - despite the poorly disguised PR attempt to mend his relationship with Ten Hag.

headline: Man Utd stars' brutal antics after Phil Neville arrived at training ground in Ferrari
body: Phil Neville and a Ferrari don't belong in the same sentence - hence the reaction his Manchester United team-mates had when he arrived at training behind the wheel of one
Rio Ferdinand has revealed the Manchester United squad's reaction to Phil Neville turning up to training in a flashy Ferrari.
Neville's decision to show off quickly backfired. The full-back caught his team-mates off guard as he pulled up in his new supercar, a not-so-common sight during Sir Alex Ferguson's legendary reign.

And they soon let him know their thoughts on the matter, as Ferdinand recalled on his podcast Rio Presents. The Red Devils legend said: "I remember Phil Neville turned up in a Ferrari once. Phil Neville. The Neville should not turn up anywhere in a Ferrari, alright?

"He turned up in a Ferrari once and his car got smashed with balls, like 10, 15, 20 yards away. Lads were banging balls at it, kicking balls up in the sky for it to drop on the car. Like, 'what are you doing?' That's just a subtle way of saying, 'sell that car, now'."

Ferdinand had been discussing United's potential signing of Ronaldinho alongside the club's former chief executive Peter Kenyon, who explained how he could've arrived in the summer of 2003 as well as a young Cristiano Ronaldo.
After talks with United, the Brazilian icon instead left PSG to join Barcelona. Kenyon feels that ultimately worked out positively for United, who weren't used to making signings of that ilk.

He told Ferdinand: "I think on reflection we did better without him, because coming back to culture, to what Manchester United was, it was a special team, a special environment. Ok people went out, but they didn't party every night, they didn't come to training late.

"United was bigger than any player in the world at that stage. We had conversations, Alex and I - United was so special, the best player in the world couldn't necessarily just walk onto Old Trafford and play."
Kenyon pointed out a shift in transfer approach from the days of Fergie's tenure, with Ferdinand agreeing. "I think that's part of the problem today," the 70-year-old continued.

"It's not about the best players are the ones you pay more money for or you pay more wages. That doesn't mean they're the best player for you. Every time an agent rings me, 'I've got the best left-back'. Well, he might be, but he might not be the best left-back for us. And the best teams work that out."

headline: Something unexpected could happen at Manchester United after Manuel Ugarte transfer
body: Sir Alex Ferguson famously called complacency among players a 'disease' in 2016.
The legendary former Manchester United manager understood the importance of competition for places and how fresh blood would give his players a kick up the backside.
Casemiro is a current member of the dressing room who could do with a jolt and Manuel Ugarte's imminent arrival from Paris Saint-Germain could provoke a response from him.

The Brazilian was outstanding in his first season at United but shocking in his second year. Ugarte is a mobile defensive midfielder, he will recover and intercept balls and is expected to start in front of the backline with Kobbie Mainoo and Bruno Fernandes playing ahead of him.
United have splashed €50million (£42.3m), with a further €10m (£8.5m) in add-ons to sign Ugarte and he arrived in Manchester on Tuesday to undergo his medical and finalise his move.
Fresh legs were required in United's midfield and the club believe their deal with PSG has shown their patient approach to the negotiations in this summer window has worked.

The signing of Ugarte is better later than never and he is expected to be available for selection against Liverpool on Sunday afternoon. Casemiro started the opening games of the season against Fulham and Brighton but he will now have to fight to retain his starting role.

Casemiro didn't spectacularly regress last season due to complacency, he merely looked like a player who had helplessly entered the winter of his career, which was sad to see, but perhaps Ugarte's arrival will provide him with the spark he needs to recapture his best form.
The 2022/23 version of Casemiro might never be seen again, but Ugarte's transfer could coax improvement out of the 32-year-old, who will not want to start games on the bench.
Casemiro has enjoyed a magnificent career, winning every trophy club football has to offer, and will be offended to be included on the bench this season, regardless of his decline.

That is what Erik ten Hag wants - he would be concerned if a player wasn't aggrieved to be named on the bench. Casemiro must channel any frustration into producing better performances and his anticipated competition with Ugarte can only be positive news for United.
Of course, it's possible that Casemiro and Ugarte could play together, but that would mean dropping the excellent Mainoo and he should be one of the first names on the team sheet.

A high-placed source at United conceded Ten Hag was forced to overplay Mainoo last season. The youngster was asked to do a lot after his return from an ankle injury and he will benefit from being rotated in some matches, but he should start most Premier League games.
Fernandes is the captain and he will obviously not be rested. He is the most influential player in the squad and has been the most consistent performer since signing in January 2020.
Casemiro seemed off the pace during pre-season, but there have been signs of a possible return to form in recent weeks and he has actually looked better in more prominent midfield positions.

He seems to have a hidden magnet in his head to attract the ball when United take set-pieces and has been involved in intricate play around the box, although there are still doubts about the protection he provides to the backline and that's ultimately his biggest responsibility.

It will be fascinating to see how a battle between Ugarte and Casemiro develops this season and how Ten Hag will divide game time between the pair. Thankfully, the midfield is about to be shaken up and the chances are Ugarte will finish the campaign with more starts.

headline: Manuel Ugarte set to complete Manchester United transfer after late-night arrival
body: Manuel Ugarte is set to undergo his medical today before finalising his £42.3m transfer to Manchester United, having flown into the city late on Tuesday.

The 23-year-old landed at Manchester Airport just before 10pm last night, flying on a private jet from Paris after United agreed a fee with Paris Saint-Germain to end their summer-long pursuit. United will pay an initial €50m, with a further €10m in add-ons.

Now he has arrived in Manchester Ugarte is expected to complete the formalities of his move today. The Uruguay international has set his sights on a switch to Old Trafford throughout the summer and he has been United's top target for the holding midfield position.

Ugarte will need to be registered with the Premier League before midday on Friday to be in contention to feature against Liverpool on Sunday, although he hasn't played for Paris Saint-Germain since the Copa America, having been left out of their matchday squad for their first two Ligue 1 fixtures of the season.
United are pleased with the deal they have struck for Ugarte, with PSG holding firm on a demand for a fixed fee of €60m until a fresh round of negotiations late last week.
Ugarte made the Copa America Best XI at this summer's tournament in the United States, which further enhanced United's view of him as one of the best young midfielders in the game.

United had also explored alternative options in midfield, but their interest in Real Sociedad's Martin Zubimendi cooled quickly while a return for Sofyan Amrabat was always seen as less attractive than signing Ugarte, who impressed for Uruguay in this summer's Copa America.

Although it has taken a while to agree the terms of a deal, key figures in United's new-look football structure had expressed confidence two weeks ago that they would land Ugarte before this Friday's deadline, which is why he had remained their top target for so long.
Ugarte will become the fifth signing of the window and will take the club's spending to over £200m. He follows the additions of Leny Yoro, Joshua Zirkzee, Matthijs de Ligt and Noussair Mazraoui.

headline: Shock Raheem Sterling deal could present Manchester United with an unwanted transfer decision for 2025
body: Three years ago Marcus Rashford, Raheem Sterling and Jadon Sancho were in the England squad that came within in a penalty shoot-out of winning a major tournament. Sancho was 21, Rashford 23 and Sterling 26 and they looked to be part of a bright future.

Now, they all find themselves at something of a crossroads. Back then, Sancho was heading for a return to the Premier League after an electric spell at Borussia Dortmund, Rashford had just had a second successive 20-goal season and Sterling was a key part of Manchester City's title winners.

In elite-level football, life can come at you fast. Now aged between 24 and 29, all three should be at their peak, but none of them made the cut for England's Euro 2024 squad. Sancho and Sterling find themselves out of the picture at Manchester United and Chelsea respectively and while Rashford's situation is perhaps the most secure for now, his status at his boyhood club is hanging by a thread.

One solution to Sancho and Sterling's predicaments at Old Trafford and Stamford Bridge is a swap deal, something the clubs have discussed this week, with the clock ticking towards Friday's deadline. United want to get rid of Sancho, who is surplus to requirements, while Chelsea are desperate to get rid of Sterling's wages.

If it comes off, and it's still probably more unlikely than likely at this stage, it would be a move of convenience. Sancho's days are numbered at United because of his falling out with Erik ten Hag last season and the absence of trust within that relationship, but also because United have four wingers to cover two positions. Adding Sterling into that mix isn't necessary from a squad-building point of view, but could be considered opportune.

The 29-year-old has 123 career goals in the Premier League for Liverpool, Manchester City and Chelsea. He is a big-game player with plenty of experience and could certainly add something to the dressing room at Old Trafford. While Sancho has little chance of making a matchday squad at the moment, Sterling would expect to feature. It would complicate selection decisions for Ten Hag going forward, especially if he intends to leave a winger out every week.

Alejandro Garnacho has started the first three games on the bench but would expect to be in the team soon. Amad has leapfrogged Antony on the right and the Brazilian's future next summer must be in doubt.

Sterling can play on the left and the right, but is better on the left and having often competed with Rashford at international level, that rivalry could be renewed at Carrington. A swap deal involving Sterling and Sancho might solve short-term problems for both players, but could also make life more difficult for Rashford.

This has felt like a make-or-break season for the academy graduate and although he's started the first three games, the campaign hasn't begun as he would have hoped. He was taken off after 65 minutes against Brighton and is already coming under pressure for his place. On merit, Garnacho deserves to start against Liverpool this weekend, but Rashford's stellar record against those opponents might hand him another chance.

Rashford managed just eight goals last season and his status as one of the highest earners in the squad after signing a new five-year deal in July 2023 is a problem if his level doesn't improve. His off-field indiscretions also frustrated Ten Hag last season.

Long-term, it's hard to see how Rashford and Sterling co-exist in a squad that also includes Garnacho. The Argentine has started to look productive on the right but feels his long-term future is on the left.

If this deal does come off before Friday, Sterling might consider it good news and an unexpected opportunity at a club bigger than Chelsea. For Rashford, it will only add to his concerns about his future. If he ends up below his former England colleague in Ten Hag's thoughts, then his future could become a major issue during the 2025 summer transfer window.

Rashford's status as the academy's poster boy has diminished recently and his relationship with supporters has frayed. For much of last season, it looked like a parting of the ways might suit every party. But actually going ahead with that is a decision both club and player would take reluctantly. Once those ties are severed they can't be reconnected, but adding more competition in his position could push things in that direction.
Sancho, Rashford and Sterling should all be at their best at this stage of their careers. Instead, the future for all three is uncertain and intertwined.

headline: Raheem Sterling could grab sentimental shirt number if he signs for Manchester United
body: Raheem Sterling will not be able to claim his favoured No.7 shirt at Manchester United if he completes a surprising move to Old Trafford. However, there's one sentimental option that might take his fancy.

Sterling has emerged as a late target for United this summer after being unceremoniously cast aside by Chelsea in the final stages of the transfer window. United have held exploratory discussions on a potential swoop, while they are now seemingly involved in a three-way transfer triangle involving Chelsea and Juventus.

Juventus and Chelsea both want Jadon Sancho and a swap deal involving the United forward and Sterling has also been mooted. Well-placed sources expect the parties involved will reassess that proposal, with enough time to get business rubber-stamped before 11pm comes and goes on Friday night.

Sterling is certainly no stranger to the north west. The 29-year-old spent five years at Liverpool between 2010 and 2015 after leaving QPR, while the 82-cap England star went on to win ten major honours with Manchester City in a seven-year haul which included four Premier League medals under Pep Guardiola.

Despite those connections, it would be a dream come true for Sterling to play for United as he grew up in London supporting the Old Trafford giants. However, while he might have initially wanted to take the No.7 shirt he wore for City, that particular shirt number is not available to him.

Mason Mount, who incidentally took the direct route from Stamford Bridge to United himself last summer, has the iconic No.7 to his name. Sterling's other previous choices are also predominately taken.
No.13, No.19, No.26, No.27, No.28, No.29 and No.30 among the shirt numbers yet to be assigned this season. Sterling, or other potential signings, also have several alternatives in the 30s and 40s.

However, the one that might really catch his eye is No.31, which the forward donned throughout his five-year spell with United's bitter rivals Liverpool. That was last 'owned' by former loan goalkeeper Jack Butland.
Failing that, No.27 probably looks to be the best bet as he initially wore No.17 with Chelsea.

headline: When is the Europa League draw? Date and time as Manchester United discover opponents
body: Manchester United's journey in the Europa League will officially kick-off this week when they find out their opponents for the group phase.

The remaining teams will be eliminated and will not drop into the Conference League. With that said, MEN Sport brings you all the information on how to follow the draw.
The Europa League draw is scheduled for Friday, August 30, taking place Monte Carlo, Monaco. The draw will begin at 12pm BST.

headline: Jadon Sancho sends indirect message to Erik ten Hag amid Man United transfer talks
body: Manchester United winger Jadon Sancho has shown Erik ten Hag what he can offer the club despite talks commencing surrounding his future.

The Turin club's stance has strengthened on Wednesday with Federico Chiesa en-route to Liverpool after agreeing a move to Anfield. Such a transfer should give Juve enough wiggle room in their budget to get Sancho in, if they so desire.

headline: I heard Dimitar Berbatov's Rasmus Hojlund verdict but he is forgetting one major thing
body: Manchester United's big summer signing last season was Rasmus Hojlund and at just 21 he was thrown straight into the deep end at Old Trafford.
Following the departure of Cristiano Ronaldo, United had been scrambling for a centre-forward. First Wout Weghorst was brought in as a stop gap but he was certainly not prolific.

The idea was to sign Harry Kane or a striker of a similar ilk and Hojlund but United could only get one deal done. Couple this with Anthony Martial's injury woes and suddenly the Dane was the club's only recognised striker.

Goals were at a premium for players behind him so in general it made for a difficult experience for Hojlund. But to his credit, in 43 matches in all competitions the striker bagged 16 goals, a respectable tally in a terrible campaign for United, especially in the Premier League.

Hojlund has missed the beginning of the season due to injury but that has not stopped club legend Dimitar Berbatov suggesting the Dane needs to do more. "Hojlund's goal ratio must improve," the Bulgarian told Futbin.
"He should be better and I think he can be better. He can do better but it comes down to concentration levels.

"Keeping his concentration levels high throughout all the games because he had good goal-scoring opportunities and didn't score them." While this could be considered to be fair criticism, Berbatov seems to have forgotten how his first season at Old Trafford fared.

Coincidentally, both players played the same amount of matches in their first seasons with Berbatov scoring two less goals than Hojlund. In the Premier League, Hojlund played one fewer game than the Bulgarian but scored one more goal.

In fact, Hojlund's goals to game ratio is better than Berbatov's across the board in that first season barring the FA Cup where they both scored just the one goal but the 43-year-old did it in three matches instead of five. You could even argue that Hojlund's figures are more impressive considering the extenuating circumstances at the club compared to the 2008/09 season.

Hojlund is undoubtedly wanting to improve and become a 20+ goals per season striker for the Reds but it takes time to adapt to new surroundings. Perhaps insisting he should already doing better than some greats did in their first seasons is unrealistic and there is certainly no need to panic just yet.

headline: Man United transfer decision branded 'pathetic' by fuming World Cup winner
body: Bayern Munich and Germany legend Lothar Matthaus has branded his former club as pathetic for allowing Manchester United to sign Matthijs de Ligt this summer.

The Dutch centre-back has been on the radar of Erik ten Hag since he arrived at Old Trafford. In his first summer, United's boss could not find the resources to persuade De Ligt to move to the Premier League especially when he was considered a key player in Bavaria.

However, an injury to De Ligt left him out of favour with Thomas Tuchel and seemingly the Bayern boardroom with the defender left to play a bit-part role at the Allianz Arena. When the summer came, the former Ajax man was keen for a reunion with Ten Hag and after delays to the completion of the deal, De Ligt eventually signed in the lead-up to the opening match of the Premier League season.

While United are undoubtedly pleased to be strengthening their defence, Matthaus has attacked Bayern for what he perceives to be poor negotiations in the transfer window. He told Sky Deutschland: "The defence is and remains Bayern’s Achilles heel.
"Matthijs de Ligt was sold, even though he was the most stable defender over the past two years. He was the leader of the backline.
"Now Bayern are again looking for a successor to David Alaba. For me, it’s pathetic that this leader is missing.
"After all, we are talking about FC Bayern. All the centre-backs currently in the Bayern squad have to be clear with themselves first.
"If De Ligt had not been sold, I would not have worries at FC Bayern now. But my opinion about him is probably different to the people in charge.
"It’s a decision that has to be accepted. But many – including within the team – are just shaking their heads.
"Because the players also know that their defence is shaky. And then the best defender for many is sold."

headline: Raheem Sterling has shown Manchester United his true colours ahead of proposed transfer
body: Raheem Sterling made his name in the north west during ten successful years with Liverpool and Manchester City, combined. However, the Chelsea outcast actually grew up supporting rivals Manchester United.

Speculation over Sterling and his Stamford Bridge future remains at fever pitch and The Manchester Evening News understands Ineos have held exploratory discussions over a potential move. The winger has emerged as a would-be addition late on this summer in a three-way transfer triangle involving Chelsea, Juventus and United.
