headline: Rio Ferdinand recalls Man Utd stars' brutal reaction to Phil Neville arriving in Ferrari
body: Rio Ferdinand has recalled the time Phil Neville turned up to Manchester United training in a Ferrari.
The younger Neville brother was soon made to regret that decision when his team-mates reacted in brutal fashion. He was far from the flashiest member of Sir Alex Ferguson's squad.

And that's why Ferdinand, who played alongside him for three seasons, and Co couldn't believe their eyes when he drove in behind the wheel of his supercar. Speaking on his podcast Rio Presents, the former centre-back said: "I remember Phil Neville turned up in a Ferrari once.
"Phil Neville. The Neville should not turn up anywhere in a Ferrari, alright? He turned up in a Ferrari once and his car got smashed with balls, like 10, 15, 20 yards away.
"Lads were banging balls at it, kicking balls up in the sky for it to drop on the car. Like, 'what are you doing?' That's just a subtle way of saying, 'sell that car, now'."

Ferdinand had been discussing the potential arrival of Ronaldinho to Old Trafford with former chief executive Peter Kenyon. The Brazilian icon had been in talks with the Red Devils prior to joining Barcelona from PSG in 2003.
Kenyon explained how United could well have signed both him and Cristiano Ronaldo in the same summer window. But he thinks it could've rocked the boat in a damaging manner.

The 70-year-old said: "I think on reflection we did better without him, because coming back to culture, to what Manchester United was, it was a special team, a special environment. Ok people went out, but they didn't party every night, they didn't come to training late.

"United was bigger than any player in the world at that stage. We had conversations, Alex and I – United was so special, the best player in the world couldn't necessarily just walk onto Old Trafford and play."

Kenyon suggested it's that mentality which has largely been lost since the days of Fergie's legendary reign, with Ferdinand agreeing with him. "I think that's part of the problem today," he continued.

"It's not about the best players are the ones you pay more money for or you pay more wages. That doesn't mean they're the best player for you. Every time an agent rings me, 'I've got the best left-back' – well, he might be, but he might not be the best left-back for us. And the best teams work that out."

headline: Manchester United trying to arrange two loan departures before transfer deadline day
body: Manchester United are hopeful that loans can be agreed for Sonny Aljofree and Elyh Harrison before the transfer deadline.
Aljofree, 19, and goalkeeper Harrison, 18, have both been identified as young players who would benefit from a loan spell and movement is anticipated before the window shuts.
Clubs who sign United's youngsters on loan must pitch their development plan for the player and talks are progressing for loan moves for both Aljofree and Harrison.

Aljofree signed for Altrincham on a flexi-loan in the January transfer window and spent a few months around the non-league side's squad. The innovative loans allow youngsters to gain senior experience whilst remaining involved in the day-to-day environment at Carrington.
Centre-back Aljofree didn't make an appearance for Altrincham, but the flexi-loan system has been effective elsewhere, helping Sam Mather to develop at Rochdale, for example.
Harrison spent last season playing games for United's Under-21s and Under-18s, and he was named Reserve Player of the Year at the end of the campaign for his superb performances.
The young goalkeeper was brilliant in between the sticks throughout 2023/24 and his shot-stopping display was crucial in the U18s' victory in the PL Cup against Manchester City.
Harrison is a ball-playing 'keeper, whose distribution is a strength, and he did a Cruyff turn with Stockport's striker closing him down at Edgeley Park in the EFL Trophy last year.
There are high hopes for Harrison in the academy and United believe they have a goalkeeper who has the potential to break into the first-team, which will eventually be his target.
Harrison signed his first-ever professional contract with United in March 2023 and that came a year after joining the club from Stevenage Town on a scholarship deal.
The goalkeeper signed his pro deal immediately after celebrating his 17th birthday, which is the earliest possible date a talented young player can be given pro terms.

headline: Manchester United's game model is benefiting one of their signings
body: Manchester United's flight back from Brighton was delayed by two hours on Saturday. Their season is yet to take off.

There are three glaring issues with United: their attackers don't score, there midfield is nigh-on non-existent and their defenders cannot see out games. Joao Pedro's header was the seventh added-time winner United have conceded under Erik ten Hag.
They have also suffered draws that felt like a defeat against Crystal Palace, Sevilla, Brentford and Coventry City. Ten Hag bristled at the suggestion their game management was inept.

"I think we also often did the right things," he stated, "that we often had success. For instance, when we win the trophies and there were many other big games we take the points. On this occasion today we should do better.
"On many occasions we have done very good in situations where we brought the score over the line and take the result."
Ten Hag dined alone in Hale on Sunday. Even with a teeming brains trust in the dugout to support him he will have felt lonely in the technical area in the 95th minute at Brighton.

His in-game management brought upon United's collapse. Replacing Bruno Fernandes for Scott McTominay when the United captain's influence was growing was illogical and so was the unenforced withdrawal of Harry Maguire for Matthijs de Ligt. It is an unwritten rule in management not to disrupt your back four in-game. Antony's sole impact was to concede a cynical foul.

McTominay was the right substitute for the wrong man. Kobbie Mainoo has looked weary since his return and Casemiro is on his last legs. Somehow, both midfielders saw out a game where United's midfield was second-best.

"That (conceding in added time)'s very disappointing, yeah," Ten Hag admitted. "Because in the Community Shield we concede just before time, we should be more clinical in such situations, read the game, take the point if you can't win any more. We were close to winning this game but definitely don't lose the game."

Sending McTominay on suggested it was win-or-bust. McTominay is nicknamed 'McTerminator' and his function is akin to Arnold Schwarzenegger's robotic responses: score goal, kick ball, head ball or tackle.

McTominay is one of the tallest and most physical athletes in the United squad yet he shrank when Simon Adingra's cross found the unmarked Pedro. With a completely different attacking quartet on for the end of the match, United were disorganised and led by temporary captain Casemiro, whose English is limited.

Despite one win from three games, United are a more competent and composed team in possession with 'game model' the new buzz phrase. Their approach play was encouraging again and they have created nine good or great chances without converting any of them in their matches this month.

They are second in the expected goals table. One does not require such pseudo-intellectual standings to know United have been creative in the final third and one hopes Ten Hag does not refer to it at Carrington on Thursday. Coming second in it will not secure Champions League qualification next year.

United's profligacy boils down to the absence of a dependable and proven goalscorer. They have taken a risk in investing more than £108.5million in two strikers at an identical age and with identically modest goalscoring records in Italy. Joshua Zirkzee will think twice about sliding towards goal when the ball is out of reach in the future.

It was barely a footnote, but Mason Mount had his best and most meaningful half for United in Hove. The extent of Mount's "issue" that forced him off at half-time is yet to be established but after his laudable work off the ball against Fulham he was also effective on it at Brighton. That work ethic and willingness to lead the charge was evident when he penned in Jan Paul van Hecke and immediately beckoned his teammates up the pitch.

United do not currently have that urgency in the middle third. Mainoo is more conductor than destructor. He favours playing with Casemiro yet Ten Hag started phasing him out with his FA Cup final demotion.

Only the United hierarchy are taking until the final week of the transfer window to bring in a replacement. Manuel Ugarte is, unlike Mount, an out-and-out central midfielder and would bring impetus to an area where one midfielder has his bags packed, another is going next year and another may follow him out. Christian Eriksen warmed up at Brighton but is still out in the cold.
If there was an acceptable offer for him this week, he would be allowed to take off.

headline: Cristiano Ronaldo confirms retirement plan and reveals dream final transfer
body: Former Manchester United star Cristiano Ronaldo has signalled his days as a professional player are winding down, revealing that he anticipates hanging up his boots within the next three years.

Despite entering the twilight of his illustrious career, Ronaldo maintains he's not done with the sport just yet. After a high-profile and controversial departure from United, Ronaldo has been plying his trade in the Saudi Pro League with new side Al-Nassr since December 2022.

The 39-year-old veteran, renowned for his spells at United and an extraordinary nine years at Real Madrid, took a step back from the European limelight with his move. Yet his presence was felt at Euro 2024 playing for Portugal, which looks likely to be his farewell to European competition participation.

In a discussion with NOW, Ronaldo said: "I don't know if I will retire soon, in two or three years... but probably I will retire here at Al-Nassr. I'm very happy at this club, I feel good in this country too. I'm happy to play in Saudi Arabia and I want to continue."

The forward started every match for Portugal at Euro 2024 without finding the net but has had a fruitful start at Al-Nassr, netting three times in the opening trio of matches. Despite the lack of goals in the European tournament, Ronaldo is hopeful for another chance to represent his country in the upcoming Nations League fixtures slated for September, reports the Mirror.
Ronaldo has hinted that his international career may be nearing its end, but for now, he remains focused on playing and has dismissed any notions of transitioning into coaching.
"When I leave the national team, I won't tell anyone in advance and it will be a very spontaneous decision on my part, but also a very well thought-out one," Ronaldo stated.

"Right now what I want is to be able to help the national team in their upcoming matches. We have the Nations League ahead of us and I would really like to play. At the moment, I'm not thinking about being a coach of the first team or any team."
"It doesn't even cross my mind, I've never thought about it. I don't see my future going through that. I see myself doing other things outside of football, but only God knows what the future holds."

Portugal manager Roberto Martinez has set his sights on winning the 2026 World Cup, a tournament that Ronaldo may have retired from by then. However, the Spanish boss still sees the superstar as a crucial player for his team.

"When we talk about Cristiano, we are talking about a striker who scores goals. But our striker is much more than this. I was happy with his discipline. He opened up spaces, reacted to losing the ball, and I think the lack of goals from Cristiano was shared in general around the team," he told zerozero.
"We lacked goals from players in the box, from Rafael Leao, Bruno Fernandes and Bernardo Silva, for example. What Ronaldo did as a striker was what we expected from him. Overall he worked very well."

headline: Jadon Sancho Man United transfer twist as important £8m deal confirmed and new priority revealed
body: Juventus have confirmed the signing of attacker Francisco Conceicao from Porto in a deal that could impact how Manchester United and Jadon Sancho operate in the final week of the transfer window. The Old Lady are already in talks to add the 24-year-old to their ranks as well.

Any deal for Sancho was going to come after Conceicao's arrival in Turin as Thiago Motta sets about getting his side back to being title challengers in Italy Without Conceicao, who cost a reported £6million plus a possible £2million in add-ons, Juve beat Verona 3-0 on Monday with goals coming from Dusan Vlahovic and Nicolo Savona.
The transfer priority moving forward for Juventus is still thought to be away from Sancho though. Atalanta's in-demand midfield Teun Koopmeiners is the next player on their radar.

According to Fabrizio Romano a medical for the Dutch international has already been booked in with a deal ready to be completed before long. Only then will that leave Sancho as the player at the forefront of their mind.

Formal discussions over a possible move for the Englishmen have already started after Sancho's camp flew to Italy on Monday. United are keen to get him off the books completely with a permanent transfer but are also open to a loan.

Due to the amortised cost of his contract - which still has two years left to run - United would need over £30million to bank a profit in the accounts, although it will remain an enormous net loss having spent over £72million to bring him in from Borussia Dortmund.

Sancho has been left out of United's matchday squads for the opening two games of the season so far. He did travel with his teammates to Brighton on Saturday though, only to watch them eventually lose 2-1 after Joao Pedro's late goal.

The former Manchester City academy starlet has repaired his relationship with Erik ten Hag having fallen out last season. He was reintegrated into the senior setup at Old Trafford but is still pursuing opportunities elsewhere with United possessing other wingers.
Amad and Alejandro Garnacho have both impressed in the opening weeks of the new season. Marcus Rashford and Antony can also play out wide.

headline: How Manchester United plan to use unsellable player
body: Manchester United centre back Victor Lindelof will also be used as cover in the full back positions in the likely event that he stays at the club.

Lindelof, 30, has not trained in more than three weeks due to a toe problem and only played two halves during pre-season. United are set to be saddled with a player they have sought to sell for the majority of the summer.
The Sweden captain is one of four defenders currently sidelined through injury and United sources have namechecked Lindelof among the players who could provide cover at left back.
Lindelof started six times at left back last season and replaced Luke Shaw there at half-time away at Aston Villa and Luton Town. United lost three of the six games Lindelof lined up at left back.
United have no intention of moving for a stop-gap left back ahead of Friday's transfer deadline, having signed Sergio Reguilon on loan from Tottenham on deadline day last year.
Shaw is expected to return from a calf injury after the September internationals and Tyrell Malacia has been slated for an October return from a long-term knee problem.

United have started the season with Diogo Dalot at left back and new signing Noussair Mazraoui is also an option to play there. Seventeen-year-old left back Harry Amass has been promoted to the first team squad after his fine form during the pre-season tour.
United triggered the one-year extension in Lindelof's contract in December when they could have released him in June.

headline: Manchester United stance on possible Raheem Sterling move
body: Manchester United are wary of making an approach for Chelsea outcast Raheem Sterling despite the winger's interest in joining the club.
Sterling, 30, would be open to a move to United if Juventus fail to progress with a deal for Jadon Sancho.
A possible swap involving England internationals Sancho and Sterling has been touted with United keen to sell the former while the latter was stripped of the number seven at Chelsea.

Sancho earns around £250,000-a-week, which will have reduced following United's failure to qualify for the Champions League. Sterling is on a £325,000 weekly salary at Chelsea, which would leave United worse off under the Premier League's profitability and sustainability rules.

United have stressed they would only be prepared to do deals that would aid their profitability and sustainability calculations for next year. United also have two wingers on the right and left-hand sides, with Bruno Fernandes and Mason Mount also options on the right.

Chelsea want to sell Sterling after he was left out of their opening game of the season against Manchester City. The winger's representatives published a statement before kick-off seeking "clarity" on his role and Sterling is now training away from the first team squad.
Sterling grew up supporting United and has remarkably never scored against them in 26 appearances for Liverpool, City and Chelsea.

United have no plans to move for Sterling's fellow Chelsea outcast, Ben Chilwell. Chelsea want to sell the left back and United are currently devoid of their senior left backs, Luke Shaw and Tyrell Malacia, due to injury.

Right back Diogo Dalot has started the season at left back and new signing Noussair Mazraoui is also able to play there. Seventeen-year-old left back Harry Amass was promoted to the first team squad after his impressive pre-season tour performances.
Shaw is expected to return from a calf injury next month while manager Erik ten Hag has suggested Malacia could recover from a knee problem that has caused him to miss the last 15 months in October.
United held discussions with Chelsea about a mooted loan move for left back Marc Cucurella last year after Shaw suffered a hamstring injury two games into the season.

headline: When is the Carabao Cup draw? Time and third round rules for Man City and Man United
body: The Carabao Cup has continued this week, with more teams set to join the competition from the next round.
At the weekend, both Manchester United and Manchester City were in Premier League action. Pep Guardiola's side cruised past Ipswich Town and sealed a 4-1 win at the Etihad Stadium.

United meanwhile, fell to a 2-1 defeat against Brighton, their first defeat of the season after Joao Pedro scored the winner during stoppage time. As well City and United, teams such as Liverpool and Arsenal will all join the competition and will discover their third-round opponents in this week's draw.
With that said, the Manchester Evenings has all the details for the Carabao Cup third round draw below:
The draw for the third round will take place on Wednesday (August 28) after the conclusion of the second-round match between Nottingham Forest and Newcastle United at the City Ground.
The game will kick-off at 8pm and the draw will take place shortly after.
A total of 32 teams will participate in the third-round draw of the Carabao Cup.

Here is a complete list of the teams that will be in the third-round draw: Manchester City, Manchester United, Liverpool, Everton, Arsenal, Chelsea, Tottenham, Aston Villa, Brighton, Leicester City, Fulham, Crystal Palace, Stoke City, Barnsley, Barrow, Blackpool, Coventry City, Fleetwood Town, Sheffield Wednesday, Preston North End, Leyton Orient, QPR, Bolton Wanders, Walsall, Watford, Wolves or Burnley, AFC Wimbledon or Ipswich Town, Cardiff City or Southampton, Colchester United or Brentford, Swansea City or Wycombe Wanderers, West Ham or Bournemouth, Nottingham Forest or Newcastle United.

The Champions League format revamp has led to a new rule change affecting the Carabao Cup third-round draw. The upcoming round of the cup competition will be divided over two separate weeks, and six of the seven teams competing in Europe cannot be drawn against each other.

Consequently, Liverpool, Arsenal, Man City, Man United, Tottenham and Aston Villa will be drawn first, followed by the remaining 26 teams. Chelsea are not included in the initial draw due to the Europa Conference League league phase beginning in October, providing they get past Servette in the qualifying round. This means City and United will not be able to play each other in this round.

headline: Man United must avoid major £45m Ivan Toney transfer mistake in Chelsea battle
body: Ivan Toney looks set to leave Brentford this summer with Manchester United given the perfect opportunity to sign an elite striker.

The 28-year-old has emerged as one of the Premier League's best forwards having scored 72 goals in 141 appearances since joining the Bees from Peterborough in September 2020. Toney is also regarded as one of the best penalty takers in world football having netted 30 spot kicks, missing just two.

It's why this is such a good opportunity for someone to sign a striker who is clearly available with just days left of the summer transfer window. Toney's Brentford contract will expire next summer and with no signs of an extension, the West London club will be keen to sell and earn a healthy profit.

Interest from Chelsea and Saudi Arabia has emerged this summer and United have been previously linked. Having only ever won the EFL trophy in his career, staying in England is likely to hold greater appeal.

And after winning two trophies in two seasons under Erik ten Hag and with ambitious plans for the future under Ineos, United could be the perfect destination. Whilst a move to Chelsea may have the appeal of staying in London, the chaotic project at Stamford Bridge should dissuade some new signings.

There is no guarantee that either club will compete for major trophies in the future but United's recent success of picking up silverware and a sensible transfer strategy under Ineos should be more attractive. For United, the question is whether they need another striker.

Rasmus Hojlund and Joshua Zirkzee are two players who are still developing but have plenty of potential. Could signing Toney who is likely to regularly start, stunt the growth of two talented forwards?

However, on the balance of United missing so many good chances in pre-season and the early stages of the new campaign, a more proven goalscorer may be what Ten Hag's team need. The Reds scored just 57 goals in the top flight last season, the joint-lowest in the top 10.

Of course, PSR restraints could prevent a move for Toney. Brentford are said to have put a £70million price tag on him earlier this summer but that fee has reportedly been revised down to around £45m.

Several more sales at Old Trafford may boost United's hopes of securing a deal. Scott McTominay and Jadon Sancho are possible exits before Friday's deadline, however, the money generated may just keep the club in line with PSR ahead of Manuel Ugarte's arrival from PSG.
If a move can be funded for Toney, with so much at stake as United chase a return to the Champions League, it should be too big of an opportunity to turn down.

headline: Scott McTominay was flawed at Manchester United - but what he did at Carrington was priceless
body: Manchester United are selling Scott McTominay to Napoli for £25million.
McTominay has been at the club since the age of five but the sale of the academy graduate to Napoli after a summer of interest from Fulham makes sense.

Selling academy players represents total profit in the financial books and so McTominay's departure will help United operate within PSR restrictions. The money generated from his exit is being used to sign Manuel Ugarte.
United are offloading a player who would have started the majority of the games on the bench to sign Ugarte from PSG, who could potentially transform their midfield.
When the argument is presented like that, it was a no-brainer to sell McTominay this summer, but the decision wasn't that simple following the best season of the player's career.

"Du, du, du, du, du, Scott McTominay," was sung by United fans in the Stretford End during the opening game of the season and he received rapturous applause when he was brought on. McTominay is a boyhood United fan, he progressed through the academy and fans who regularly chanted his name last term will feel it's bittersweet to see him pack his bags for Italy.

McTominay was a flawed player but he was United through and through. He didn't pull up any trees in the academy, but he did brilliantly to break into the first team during Jose Mourinho's tenure and even better to establish himself in the dressing room after his senior bow.

It's an outstanding achievement to make a debut for United but the bigger challenge is to stay in the team. That's the toughest challenge of them all and Kobbie Mainoo, Alejandro Garnacho, Marcus Rashford and McTominay are the most recent players to have done just that.

McTominay stands out from that list because the other three players are considered to be more 'talented'. However, there are different ways to the top and McTominay's athleticism helped him along the way, allowing him to cope with the demands of the Premier League.

The 27-year-old scored 10 goals in all competitions last season and became a matchwinner. He tended to produce when United desperately needed a goal, scoring a brace against Brentford in October's 2-1 win, twice against Chelsea in December in another 2-1 victory and netting the winner against Aston Villa in February.
McTominay's late runs into the box suddenly became his trademark as he reinvented himself as a goalscorer and United will miss his ability to impact games when times are tough.

They will also miss his leadership qualities and understanding of the club. Different sources who have been present at Carrington over the last few years have all praised McTominay's character and how he acts around the training ground, members of staff and young players.
When results have been difficult and characters have been tested, McTominay has stood up to the scrutiny and taken responsibility in interviews when other players declined to do so.

There have been some brilliant moments during McTominay's time at the club, like his performance against PSG in the Champions League in 2019, his goal against Manchester City in the last game at Old Trafford before the pandemic and, of course, his brace against Brentford last season.

Everyone knows McTominay's limitations and that's ultimately why he's being sold, but his commitment on the pitch could never be questioned and his recent reinvention as an attacking midfielder perhaps should have happened sooner during his career at Old Trafford.
McTominay doesn't have the skill set to play in a defensive midfield role for United and was pigeonholed as that player due to his double-pivot partnership with Fred.
The McFred years won't be remembered fondly by supporters, but Fred left last summer with the best wishes of fans and McTominay will receive exactly the same.

headline: Why Christian Eriksen hasn't left Manchester United in summer transfer window
body: The CEO of Anderlecht has hinted Christian Eriksen's wage demands were too large to lure him away from Manchester United.
Anderlecht's manager was part of Thomas Frank's coaching staff at Brentford and discussed the possibility of rekindling his relationship with Eriksen earlier in the transfer window.
The Belgian club have been among the sides to be linked with a move for Eriksen, along with his former club Ajax and a handful Turkish clubs, but he remains a United player.

Eriksen's role was reduced last season and he made just 12 Premier League starts, which led to suggestions he could leave United in search of regular game time. He has entered the final year of his contract and this summer was the last chance to bank a reasonable fee for him.
Anderlecht had expressed an interest in signing Eriksen, but there are just two days remaining in the summer transfer window and he is expected to stay at Old Trafford.

“I myself have never mentioned the name Christian Eriksen, but of course, I know Christian. He is a top player who is still contracted for one year at a top club,” Anderlecht's CEO, Jesper Fredberg, told Het Nieuwsblad. "At the moment, (signing Eriksen) doesn’t seem realistic.
"But if a door suddenly opens, I want to be the first to step in. It’s not just about what Manchester United is asking for, but it will also be about the player’s salary demands in such a case.”
Although Eriksen discussed his lack of game time in the Danish press when on international duty last season, he sounded more upbeat about his future at Old Trafford in July.

"It depends what is coming and what is going," Eriksen said. "But like I said, I'm really happy, my family is settled in Manchester, I'm loving my time with United but like you said, as a player you want to play as much as possible but that's also about convincing the manager to let you play.

"So I'll turn that up, try to do my thing and I'll see where I'm at, but my feeling is I'm very happy at United. I still want to get on the pitch, obviously I'm staying the same person if I'm playing or not, trying to help if I can, but I want to be the football guy, not the social guy."
While Eriksen is settled and happy away from the pitch in Manchester with his wife and children, he has been an unused substitute in both Premier League games this season.
Eriksen has made 72 appearances for United since signing on a free transfer in 2022.

headline: Manuel Ugarte shows true colours with Darwin Nunez remark as Man United close on £50m deal
body: Manuel Ugarte is braced to brush off any criticism heading his way at Manchester United - just like Darwin Nunez has had to do at Liverpool.

The Red Devils' newest recruit will join from Paris Saint-Germain in a deal worth up to £50.7million, and he'll have fellow Copa America runner-up Nunez for company in the Premier League. A familiar face could help Ugarte bed in among his new surroundings, though the midfield general has shown all the signs of possessing a one-man army mentality.

Ugarte, 23, is an independent spirit when it comes to tackling online criticism, something Liverpool's record signing has had to endure plenty of in his career. And United's impending arrival demonstrated not only his own mental fortitude but a desire to protect those close to him when addressing the topic of social media and its impact on players.

"For example, Darwin [Nunez] had moments where he was killed badly, and that is also something that has a lot of merit when you see where he is today," Ugarte told Uruguayan broadcaster Channel 10 earlier this summer. "You have to be in the right head to get to where he got to with all the damage he got.

"When I see a teammate get hit, I sometimes feel like the next day it could be me, because people kill you the way they put you up there. The best thing is to surround yourself with people you love and trust, and not give the ball to the net, because that’s how the net is nowadays."

Ugarte - who reportedly underwent his United medical on Wednesday - acknowledged in the same interview that footballers are "very exposed" on the internet given their celebrity profiles. He's also taken a step away from social media, though he's accepting of the fact "not everyone's going to like you."

Despite becoming a big name in Portuguese football and growing his status by joining PSG, the midfield general is bound to experience another step up in attention at United. And while Ugarte has a resilient attitude to scrutiny as a whole, he suggested even he isn't invincible.

"I say this with humility, there are people who don't know anything about football and have an opinion, and maybe that comment has a lot of likes and it seems to be true," he continued. "I think it's something I handle quite well; but if something happens to me where everyone kills me, it's not good."

Thick skin will be a prerequisite if he's to thrive in his new English setting, particularly after United have splashed the cash once more this summer in their bid to return to the top. Ugarte joins new recruits Joshua Zirkzee, Matthijs de Ligt and Noussair Mazraoui in an effort to restore United's former glories, and the critics won't remain silent if they feel he's falling short.

headline: Manchester United fans frustrated as MUTV academy coverage reduced this season
body: Manchester United will continue to provide dedicated academy coverage where they can with their resources.
United's academy is the beating heart of the club and the Under-18s' stunning treble-winning season in 2023/24 shows they remain at the forefront of youth development.

The club's academy has a large following around the world and MUTV have regularly shown U18s and Under-21s fixtures over the years, so fans can keep up to date with the development of United's youngsters, but in-house coverage has been indirectly impacted by job losses.
There have been four matches between U18 and U21 level this season and MUTV didn't broadcast those games, which left fans wondering why the coverage had disappeared.

However, Friday’s U21 game against Blackburn will be shown on MUTV, along with Saturday’s U18 match against Liverpool and a source has reiterated the club recognises and appreciates the significant interest that its supporters have in the development of its youth players.
The words 'hard choices' have been used within United about what to cover and the club reluctantly feel they can't capture everything across the several different teams.
United fans have questioned why the coverage of the academy has been impacted this season but the club insist they remain committed to covering the youth system.

Earlier this year, ‘Lifeblood’, a six-part behind-the-scenes documentary series providing exclusive, in-depth insights into United's youth development programme was launched and the club website publishes an 'academy weekly' column each week that rounds up the latest news.
There are exclusive academy interviews in every matchday programme and in each edition of the club’s monthly magazine and United insist that will continue to be the case.

Speaking at the latest fans' forum, United's chief operating officer, Collette Roche, explained the decision to make redundancies and said: "There will be other departures too as we continue to restructure the club to ensure we have the right people in the right roles for long-term success.
"Significant transformation is required to meet the challenges we face to be successful on and off the pitch. We believe greater efficiency can lead to better outcomes.
"The cost review has identified “non-essential” activities we can stop, and we therefore believe we have more people than we need to deliver future club priorities.

"We are proposing a club-wide redundancy programme, which we believe will reduce headcount by 250 roles. There is now a formal consultation underway with colleagues so I can’t say any more about the process until that is completed.
"But we have not taken this decision lightly and would not be doing it if we didn’t feel it was necessary for the long-term health and success of the club."

headline: Ian Wright's Bruno Fernandes Man United theory will leave Erik ten Hag furious
body: Arsenal legend Ian Wright believes Manchester United's captain Bruno Fernandes was laughing at Erik ten Hag after being substituted in the defeat to Brighton and Hove Albion.

The Reds found themselves 1-0 down at the interval after Danny Welbeck tapped home from close range to give the hosts the lead. At half-time, it was clear something needed to change with Joshua Zirkzee being introduced to allow Fernandes to drop deeper into his preferred No.10 role.

United's change had the desired effect on the hour mark as Amad's deflected strike brought the visitors level. Alejandro Garnacho thought he had made it 2-1 shortly afterwards but his goal was ruled out for offside after an agonising touch by the offside Zirkzee on the line.

Instead of pushing for the winner in the final ten minutes, Ten Hag chose to try and consolidate the point as Scott McTominay was introduced for Fernandes. The Portuguese midfielder looked unimpressed by the decision as he left the field and ultimately it would backfire.

Brighton won the game with the last chance of the game as Joao Pedro headed home unmarked at the back stick to win it for the Seagulls. Following the match, Wright told his podcast Wrighty’s House that he saw Fernandes do something that would likely unimpress his manager.

"A lot of things happened in that game that I just couldn’t understand or see happening," the former Match of the Day pundit said. "Like I can’t understand why he took Bruno off and went so defensive.
"Why are you taking him off? When he ran off, he was actually smiling and laughing. He was like: 'What the f***? I can't believe this guy.
"That’s the vibe I got from it. If anyone is going to win a game for you it’s Bruno Fernandes."

Ten Hag has shown a lot of trust in Fernandes since arriving at Old Trafford. The midfielder was named captain of United in the manager's second season and recently signed a new lucrative deal at the club.

headline: Manchester United are missing their player who is two weeks away from being available
body: Manchester United are missing Rasmus Hojlund, who is currently sidelined with injury.
Hojlund scored in his first appearance of pre-season against Arsenal in Los Angeles but tweaked his hamstring after that, which saw him cautiously leave the pitch as he was replaced.
It was subsequently confirmed that Hojluind would be out for around six weeks and the game after the September international game was earmarked for his return to action.
That meant Hojlund would be unavailable to face Liverpool at Old Trafford on September 1 and he would be available for selection for the trip to St. Mary's Stadium to face Southampton.
United got their season off to a winning start, scoring with just a few minutes left to beat Fulham, but they suffered a 2-1 defeat to Brighton last weekend and there could be no complaints.
Alejandro Garnacho's goal to make it 2-1 was unfortunately disallowed due to Joshua Zirkzee touching the ball from an offside position, but nobody could say Brighton were lucky winners.

The hosts created opportunities and struck the crossbar before eventually scoring in the fifth minute of added time. Those in red shirts switched off at a pivotal moment, leaving a handful of Brighton players unmarked at the back post, and Joao Pedro took advantage.

It was schoolboy defending from United and they were punished. The challenge of facing Liverpool, who have both of their games in the league so far, comes next and Erik ten Hag may be forced to abandon the false nine system that he persisted with at the Amex Stadium.
Bruno Fernandes started as a false against Fulham and Brighton, with Mason Mount as the No.10, but the system was changed as early as half-time against Brighton on Saturday.
Zirkzee replaced Mount and played through the middle. Fernandes relocated to his natural position, but United couldn't score the goals to take the game away from Brighton.

A lack of goals was one of many problems for United last season and it looks to have spilt into the new campaign. They have never been a free-flowing, scoring team during Ten Hag's tenure, but the attack has appeared blunt in two games so far and Hojlund is clearly missed.

Zirkzee could start against Liverpool and seems likely, but he's a different player to Hojlund. The Dutchman likes to drop deep and help build up play - he has described where he likes to play as the '9.5 role' - while Hojlund likes to stretch defences with his pace and power.
Hojlund missed his fair share of chances last season and he's still a raw striker, but he provides presence down the centre and enjoyed a purple patch at the beginning of 2024.
The striker finished the campaign with 16 goals, which represented a strong return for his first season in England, and United should improve when he is available for selection again.

It's sometimes a case of you don't know what you have until it's gone. There's no denying Hojlund has improvements to make and he must sharpen his finishing, but his qualities make United a better team and he would have made tests against Fulham and Brighton easier to overcome.
Thankfully, United have to play just one more game (Liverpool) without Hojlund and fans will be hoping he hits the ground running after the September international break.
United desperately need a goalscorer and Hojlund is their closest thing to that.

headline: Manuel Ugarte drops cryptic Man United transfer hint after deal finally agreed
body: Manuel Ugarte has teased his imminent transfer to Manchester United after the club reached an agreement with Paris Saint-Germain over a deal. The 23-year-old is expected to travel to England on Tuesday in order to complete a medical ahead of signing a long-term deal.

Having chased the Uruguayan throughout the summer it will be a move that addresses a key need in Erik ten Hag's squad. United will pay an initial £42.3million for Ugarte with a possible £8.5million in add-ons.

Ugarte's transfer has been on the verge for a while now with the two European powerhouses discussing a structure after personal terms were agreed. United now believe that their patient approach has paid off with a favourable price being finalised.
Before the deal is announced - likely to come later this week - Ugarte has jumped the gun himself. Taking to Twitter/X, he simply posted a single emoji of a pair of eyes.
Perhaps indicating his excitement to join United, the PSG man is now all but certain to start a new chapter of his career. After just one season in France, Ugarte is set to exit Ligue 1.
He only made the big switch from Portugal to Paris 12 months ago but struggled to make an impact under Luis Enrique. Ugarte did impress at Copa America though.
United will add Ugarte to their midfield ranks which already includes Kobbie Mainoo, Casemiro, and Mason Mount. Scott McTominay is closing in on a sale to Napoli.
Ugarte will also join new signings Leny Yoro, Joshua Zirkzee, Matthijs de Ligt, and Noussair Mazraoui.

headline: Erik ten Hag's added-time record at Manchester United is almost the same as Sir Alex Ferguson's
body: Fergie Time began against Sheffield Wednesday but the Owls also had a hoot at Manchester United's expense. Wednesday's 1-0 win in March 1987 is the first recorded occasion where Alex Ferguson's United were beaten by an added-time goal.

During Ferguson's epoch, United only lost once in the Premier League to a goal after the 90th minute; Thierry Henry's headed winner for Arsenal in the clubs' first match at the Emirates Stadium in January 2007.

There were late losses in Europe to Deportivo la Coruna in 2001, Zalagerszeg in 2002, Bayern Munich in 2010 and Athletic Bilbao, although the latter were 2-1 up as the clock ticked past the 90th minute in their eventual 3-2 victory in March 2012.

Wimbledon triggered an FA Cup fourth round replay in January 1997, Bayern and Tottenham denied United victory in 2-2 draws in 1998-99, Costinha's conversion on the rebound inflicted an aggregate defeat and marked a watershed moment for Porto's then 41-year-old coach Jose Mourinho in March 2004. United also suffered draws that felt like defeats in north London at Arsenal in November 2007 and Tottenham in January 2013.

According to records on the comprehensive MUFC Info site, United only lost eight times to goals scored in the 90th minute and beyond across Ferguson's 26-and-a-half years as manager. In a little over two years under Erik ten Hag, United have already been beaten seven times in such a manner.

Arsenal and Brighton are responsible for two apiece. Fulham beat United with a 95th-minute strike at Old Trafford in February and Chelsea scored twice in added time to secure an extraordinary 4-3 comeback in April. Bayern Munich's 4-3 Champions League group stage victory in September was via a goal in the 92nd minute (when they were 3-2 up ahead).

In the Premier League era, United lost twice to goals scored in, or after, the 90th minute (Arsenal away in 2006-07 and Crystal Palace at home in 2019-20) before Ten Hag took over. On Ten Hag's watch, it has happened six times.

Overall, Ten Hag's United have conceded 13 goals that have caused them to draw or lose a game. The first was Michael Olise's free-kick for Palace in the 1-1 draw in January 2023. Four days later, Eddie Nketiah finished the scoring for a 3-2 win to Arsenal at the Emirates.

Harry Maguire's unfortunate own goal against Sevilla preceded United's 3-0 shellacking in the Europa League quarter-final second leg in April 2023. Brentford levelled in the 99th minute after Mason Mount's apparent 96th-minute winner in March and Coventry came from 3-0 down to make it 3-3 through Haji Wright's 95th-minute penalty in the FA Cup semi-final in April.

headline: Sir Alex Ferguson has made Scott McTominay thoughts perfectly clear amid Man Utd exit
body: Manchester United's decision to sell Scott McTominay to Napoli may not have gone down well with Sir Alex Ferguson.

The Scotland midfielder, 27, who has been associated with United since the age five, is set for pastures after United accepted a bid of £25.4million from the Italian side. McTominay made 43 appearances last season and started the 2-1 FA Cup final victory over Manchester City in May.

However, the academy graduate, who made his senior debut against Arsenal in 2017, has been deemed expendable by Erik ten Hag, who is now to set to land long-term target Manuel Ugarte from Paris Saint-Germain. After protracted negotiations, United have finally agreed a fee of €50m (£42.3m), with a further €10m (£8.5m) in add-ons.
READ MORE:United agree £42.3m Ugarte deal as transfer approach explained

McTominay's departure will disappoint many at Old Trafford, possibly including Ferguson, who signed the player as a child. Sir Alex has previously hailed the midfielder's big-game temperament, telling the Scottish FA's media channel in 2021: "Scott McTominay is now emerging as one of Man United's big players.
"When you watch Man United pick their team for a big game, McTominay's name is in it. He's a good character, a great trainer. I know a little bit about the boy and I think that's the background."

Comparing McTominay to another United stalwart, Darren Fletcher, Ferguson added: "I signed him when he was seven or eight years of age and he was actually a centre-forward as a kid. He's just sprouted, a little bit like Darren Fletcher. Darren had a few little annoying injuries as he was growing and needed some rest periods and things like that.

"McTominay is of a similar type to Darren - long, lanky, good winner of the ball and a good turn of pace going forward, a great attitude to the game. All these attitudes that Darren Fletcher had, he's got them.

"Even if you go back to my time with Darren, I very seldom left him out of big games, particularly against Arsenal. He was fantastic against Arsenal and Vieira and I had no problems. McTominay is going forward on those guidelines that Darren pursued for a long time at United. It's really rewarding for me to see a Scot coming through."

headline: Manchester United target one signing and three sales ahead of transfer deadline
body: Manchester United's provisional intention is to make one signing and sell three players ahead of Friday's transfer deadline.

United have made progress in a long-gestated move for midfielder Manuel Ugarte, who was left out of Paris Saint-Germain's matchday squad last week. PSG are open to negotiating a loan move for Ugarte if United cannot finance a permanent deal, which is contingent on the departure of Scott McTominay.
McTominay, 27, is inching closer to a move to Napoli. A final fee is not believed to have been agreed, with United holding out for £25m, but the deal is expected to be concluded.

United are looking to sell Jadon Sancho amid interest from Juventus, while Chelsea have been touted as a possible destination for the winger. Sancho, 24, was absent from the United matchday squad for the second week running at Brighton. He still travelled with the squad to the Amex Stadium.

Hannibal Mejbri is generating interest from Championship side Burnley. The 21-year-old has not started for United since November as he was loaned to Sevilla earlier this year in a deal that included an option to buy.
Mejbri is out of contract next year and this week is effectively the last chance United have to obtain a fee for a player they bought for £10m from Monaco when he was a 16-year-old.
United's preference is for straight sales unless a loan deal would help them comply with profitability and sustainability calculations.

headline: Manchester United set for discussions with Juventus over Jadon Sancho
body: Manchester United are set to hold formal discussions with Juventus over the possible sale of Jadon Sancho.

A private jet is scheduled to take off from Manchester for Turin later today amid Juve's firm interest in Sancho. United are prepared to sell Sancho as they have two wingers ahead of him in the pecking order on the right and left-hand side. The 24-year-old's sale would also aid United's profitability and sustainability calculations for next year.

Sancho has been omitted from both of United's Premier League matchday squads so far this season. He still travelled with the squad for the 2-1 defeat to Brighton on Saturday. The former Borussia Dortmund player's only appearance for United in the past year was as a substitute against Manchester City in the Community Shield earlier this month.

Sancho was banished from the United squad last September after he publicly accused manager Erik ten Hag of lying over his omission from the squad for the 3-1 defeat at Arsenal. Dortmund re-signed Sancho on loan from United in January for a loan fee rising to £6.4million and he started in their Champions League final defeat to Real Madrid.

United bought Sancho from Dortmund for £72.9m in 2021 on a five-year contract and would need a final fee of around £29.16m to comply with the amortisation - the cost of Sancho's fee over a five-year period.

Sancho and Scott McTominay could be two high-profile sales to Italy this week, with Napoli closing in on an agreement for the latter. United and Napoli were in dialogue earlier this summer amid the Italian club's interest in Mason Greenwood.

headline: Manchester United close to arranging loan deal for defender who travelled on USA tour
body: Manchester United defender Rhys Bennett is close to joining Fleetwood Town on a season-long loan.
Bennett travelled to the United States for this summer's pre-season tour and made substitute appearances against Arsenal in Los Angeles and Liverpool in South Carolina.
The centre-back wants regular game time this season and although his proposed loan to Fleetwood is yet to be complete, it should be finalised before the transfer deadline.

Fleetwood are competing in League Two after relegation from the third division and are currently managed by former Liverpool midfielder Charlie Adam. United hope the loan will help Bennett in the next stage of his development as he looks to test himself in a senior environment.

Bennett joined Stockport County on a six-month loan in the January transfer window and although he made just a single appearance at Edgeley Park, sources at Stockport described him as a 'very positive individual around the camp' and he received praise for his 'very good attitude'.
The 20-year-old thanked Stockport and said 'what an experience' on social media when his loan concluded and he featured in a handful of United Under-21 games at the end of 2023/24.
Although Bennett's loan at Stockport didn't go as planned, it is hoped the months he spent around a title-winning squad were still beneficial to his education.
Bennett captained the Under-18 team that lifted the FA Youth Cup in the 2021/2022 season, scoring the opening goal of the final against Nottingham Forest at Old Trafford.
He is still yet to make his senior United debut but made the bench against West Ham in the Premier League before Christmas and against Wigan Athletic in the FA Cup.
Bennett signed a new United contract last summer and is a local lad who was born in Denton.

headline: Manchester United's plan for Sekou Kone revealed after agreement for wonderkid transfer
body: Manchester United have agreed a deal to sign defensive midfielder Sekou Kone in this summer window.
Kone currently plays for Guidars FC and impressed playing for Mali at the Under-17 World Cup in December, but he's set to complete a transfer to United before deadline day.
Although Erik ten Hag is in the market to sign a defensive midfielder and talks for Manuel Ugarte are progressing, the plan is for Kone to join up with the Under-21s.

It's understood the 18-year-old is considered as a player with high potential by United staff and he'll spend time training with the first-team at Carrington, which means he could be fast-tracked if he demonstrates he can operate at the level required around the senior group.
Manchester is close to 2,500 away from the African nation Mali and United will help Kone integrate into life in England as he settles into his new surroundings at a young age.
When United signed Alejandro Garnacho as a teenager in 2020, he undertook intensive English lessons and was given access to documentaries on the club and Manchester.
The same treatment will be given to Kone and more because Garnacho signed during the pandemic, which limited the care the club could give him after signing from Atletico Madrid.
Travis Binnion is the U21 manager at United and he will oversee Kone in a youth programme that will provide him with challenges in the EFL Trophy and in the Premier League 2.

Kone started his career with the JMG academy in Bamako, Mail, following in the footsteps of Tottenham Hotspur and Mali international Yves Bissouma. Mali beat Argentina to claim a third-place finish at the U17 World Cup in Indonesia and Kone played a pivotal role in that success.
United have also signed youth striker Chido Obi-Martin from Arsenal this summer and they continue to add talent to their academy to remain at the forefront of youth development.

headline: Who is Jim Thwaites? The 16-year-old training with Manchester United first team ahead of Brighton
body: Manchester United are stepping up their preparations for the first away game of the 2024/15 Premier League season.

Erik ten Hag’s side started the campaign on a positive note with new signing Joshua Zirkzee getting the only goal of the game in last Friday’s 1-0 Premier League win over Fulham as the team kicked off the new campaign. Concentration now turns to the trip to Brighton.
United take on the Seagulls at the AMEX Stadium on Saturday (12.30pm kick-off). Fabian Hurzeler’s side started with a 3-0 win over Everton last weekend, leaving them at the top of the early table.

Ahead of the game, Ten Hag has been putting his first-team squad through their paces. Included in the group was teenager Jim Thwaites, who at just 16 is considered as one of the club’s leading prospects.
So who is Thwaites? MEN Sport has taken a closer look at the youngster.

Thwaites is a 16-year-old central midfielder who has come up through the youth teams at Old Trafford. He was one of 10 players to sign a first-year scholarship deal earlier this summer, with young players not able to sign professional deals until they are 17 years old.

He featured for the club’s U16, U18, and U21 sides last season, winning the Goal of the Season award at both U16 and U18 levels. He made nine appearances for the U18s, his goal being a crucial equaliser in the 2-2 draw with Derby County.

His two appearances for the development squad came as a second-half substitute in the Premier League 2 clashes against Derby and Middlesbrough. This year he is expected to be given a prominent role in the U18s side and awarded with the experience of joining in with first-team training.

Taking to Instagram after his Goal of the Season awards, the teenager promised there was ‘more to come’ in the upcoming campaign. Sharing a clip of both of the goals on his Instagram, he wrote: “Delighted to get both U16 and U18 goal of the season. More to come next season…”

He has also given his response to training with the United first team for the first time. On Wednesday night he posted a picture of his boots on his Instagram story with a caption reading: “Good first session with the first team.”

headline: New Man United signing explains reason for summer transfer as clear promise made
body: New Manchester United signing Dominique Janssen says the club's "big ambitions" helped convince her to make the switch to Marc Skinner's side and believes the Reds' FA Cup success last term will drive them on to more silverware.

Janssen joined United on a three-year deal with the option of an additional 12 months earlier in the summer following the expiration of her contract with Wolfsburg. The Netherlands defender returns to the Women’s Super League (WSL) having previously spent four seasons at Arsenal, with whom she won the league title, the FA Cup and two League Cups.

Reflecting on her decision to join the Reds in her first interview with the club, Janssen said: "I knew a little bit (about United) and their fan base is like crazy, it's really nice to get to know them and to see how the club has developed and also to see where we can go with the team.

"The club have big ambitions. The growth they have been making the past six years since they have started has also been really good. Of course there will also be some bumps in the road which I heard from the girls as well that last season was maybe was not the easiest season.

"But it's about knowing the up and downs are just part of the journey and it's so exciting to see where we can go in the next few years. That's what also drew me to the club, the potential we have in the next few years. I want to help the club and I want to do it together with the girls."

Last season was a disappointing one for United as they finished fifth in the WSL, winning just 10 of their 22 league games. However, the Reds did manage to secure the club's first major women's trophy by beating Tottenham Hotspur to the FA Cup and Janssen believes this will spur Skinner's side on to achieving more success next term.
"That's the goal," she said. "I'm hungry for more trophies and I think also they got last year the first trophy, so I think they're hungry for more trophies as well."

The defender added: "I think it has changed a lot. I have looked a little bit at the games and seeing how things are going and you see that the league is very competitive. You need to be at the top of your game every single weekend. You cannot play at 80 per cent because even the teams that are lower in the table can still beat you."

United will kick off their new WSL campaign against West Ham United on September 21 and Janssen is relishing the chance to get her first taste of representing United at Old Trafford. She said: "I think first of all just playing at Old Trafford, obviously it's called the Theatre of Dreams so I'm very excited to play there and see how many people come as well."

headline: Man United star makes trophy vow after beating Man City and Chelsea rivals to 'unbelievable' award
body: England midfielder Grace Clinton says her aim is to win trophies with Manchester United after being voted PFA Young Player of the Year.

The 21-year-old joined the Reds from Everton in 2022 though she is yet to make a competitive appearance for the club, having since enjoyed loan spells at both Bristol City and Tottenham Hotspur. Clinton excelled for the latter last term, scoring four goals and assisting four others in 20 Women's Super League (WSL) appearances and playing an integral role in Spurs’ charge to their first ever Women’s FA Cup final, though she was ineligible to play against her parent club and eventual victors United at Wembley.

Her impressive form saw her receive her first senior England call up earlier this year. She made her first full start against Austria after two appearances off the bench, and duly made an impact with her first international goal in a 7-2 win for the Lionesses.

Clinton impressed so much at Tottenham that the club were keen to make her stay in the capital permanent. “She cannot stay because she’s not a part of us next year," manager Robert Vilahamn told The Athletic in April. "But if you ask me if I want to buy her, there would be a high potential I want to do that."

However United boss Skinner has always been unequivocal in his stance on the 21-year-old, insisting that her long-term future lies in Manchester. "All I hear is Tottenham want to keep Grace, of course they want to keep Grace," he said when quizzed on the club's plans for Clinton back in May. "She's a fantastic player.

"We don't get the credit that we identified her qualities at Everton, we brought her to Manchester United, gave her six months, sent her on loan at Bristol – she got experience. She then went on loan to Tottenham to get more experience. I don't think people recognise that – there is a plan for each individual we bring into the club.
"With Grace, it's absolutely worked. I want to bring her back to the club and be part of what we're doing because I think she has a huge say in how we'll play."

And Clinton has now voiced her commitment to the Reds, insisting her ambition is to add more silverware to the club's collection. "To go to Tottenham and get confidence was just amazing," she said at the start-studded awards ceremony on Tuesday night. "And to improve obviously personally. The aim is always to win trophies with Manchester United."

On her award, Clinton added: “It’s such an honour to be voted by the unbelievable players that play in this league. It’s the best league in the world. “To go out on loan, learning as a young player and being recognized is lovely. I’ve played with confidence and when you play with that then you see the best version of a player. Tottenham have been a massive part of my journey, and I can’t thank them enough. Goals and visualisation are important to me but most of all just enjoying playing. If I’m enjoying myself then I play my best football.”

Clinton also featured in the PFA Women's Team of the Year, alongside Manchester City stars Khadija 'Bunny' Shaw, Yui Hasegawa, Lauren Hemp, Khiara Keating, Alex Greenwood, Laia Aleixandri. She beat out a host of talented players to earn the award with Lauren James, Aggie Beever-Jones, Khiara Keating, Maya Le Tissier and Jess Park among the names on the Top Six shortlist.

headline: Man United have already made history but hard work is only just beginning
body: With a deft back-post finish, Lizzie Arnot wrote her name into the annals of Manchester United history. The date was August 19, 2018 and the Scotland international ensured the Reds' long-awaited renaissance began in style by netting a last-gasp winner against bitter rivals Liverpool in the League Cup.

The setting - in front of just 829 fans at an overcast Prenton Park - belied the enormity of the occassion. This was United's first competitive game in 13 years, their first competitive outing since the Glazer regime opted to disband their senior women's team after deeming it not to be part of the club's "core business".

The team was peppered with familar faces. Alex Greenwood, now captain of Manchester City, teed up Arnot to score the winner. Lauren James, who returned to childhood club Chelsea for what was - in 2021 - a British record fee, started in midfield, while current United stars Ella Toone, Millie Turner and Leah Galton also featured.
"For a team that has only been together for six weeks they weathered the storm quite well," manager Casey Stoney told BBC Radio 5 Live after the game.

"I recruited from the second tier, they've stepped up and shown they are more than capable of playing a level above that. There's no pressure from the club to get promotion but these players want to be playing in the top flight. They're history makers now."

In spite of Stoney's measured assessment of United's ambitions, the Reds did achieve promotion at the first time of asking, subsequently finishing fourth in their first season in the Women's Super League (WSL). And now, just six years on from that League Cup victory over Liverpool, United are a card-carrying member of the top flight's elite.

Stoney's departure in the summer of 2021 was a blow but her replacement, former Birmingham City boss Marc Skinner, has presided over the most successful period in the club's history. In 2022/23, the Reds took the title race to the final day, posting a club-record points tally in the process while also reaching the FA Cup final.

Last term, despite a disappointing fifth-place finish in the WSL, United beat Tottenham Hotspur to the FA Cup trophy; a reality which would have seemed inconceivable on that momentous afternoon at Prenton Park more than half a decade ago.

While the Reds have come a tremendously long way since then, it is fair to say this summer has not been without its challenges. First came the revelataion that Skinner had been handed a one-year contract extension - a decision which was not universally popular with the United fanbase.

Then came the exodus of some of the club's biggest stars. England goalkeeper Mary Earps left to join Paris Saint-Germain (PSG), citing United's transitional state and her own ambition to compete for more silverware as her chief motivating factors. Club captain Katie Zelem also departed on a free transfer, as did fan-favourite striker Lucia Garcia.

All of this unfolded has against the backdrop of Sir Jim Ratcliffe's barely concealed apathy towards Skinner's side. The INEOS chief gave a tone-deaf interview to Bloomberg, in which he conceded plans for the women's team were "TBC".

This was swiftly followed by United Women being ousted from their state-of-the-art Carrington training facility to make way for the men's team while their own building gets a revamp, though it is understood Skinner and his players will still have access to all the necessary facilities.

Still, the emergence of reports citing concern from the Professional Footballers Association (PFA) and of agents' apparent unwillingness to throw their players into the maelstrom that is Manchester United have been concerning.

That said, the Reds have recruited shrewdly in the transfer market, with the acquisition of Brighton & Hove Albion striker Elisabeth Terland and Swedish defender Anna Sandberg, in particular, inspiring excitement, while the appointment of Dan Ashworth as sporting director inspires hope of tangible change at the club.

“Delivering a successful women’s team and a thriving, productive academy are both key objectives of my job, and I have a strong background in both areas," Ashworth said in an open letter to supporters last month.

"Women’s football was an important part of my remit in past roles with Newcastle United, Brighton & Hove Albion and the FA, and it will be the same at Manchester United. Women’s football is arguably the most exciting area of growth in the global game, and we want to be part of that.
“Last season’s FA Cup win was a fantastic landmark as our first major women’s trophy, and how we want to build on that with Marc, his staff and the players."

Indeed, six years on from that win over Liverpool, United now have all the ingredients in place to be truly successful. The Reds may already have made history in the years since their reformation but, with the WSL set to be more competitive than ever next term, it is clear the hard work is only just beginning.
